scenes.title: Ulysses Goes to Bed
scenes.summary: Ulysses is shown to his bed for the night.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Sleeping in a bed, resting
characters.quote: S'Ulysses slept in a bed placed in a room over the echoing gateway;

characters.name: Alcinous
characters.role: Lying in the inner part of the house with his wife
characters.quote: Alcinous lay in the inner part of the house, with the queen his wife by his side.

scenes.title: Banquet Assembly
scenes.summary: Alcinous gathers the Phaeacians to welcome Ulysses.
scenes.text:
BANQUET IN THE HOUSE OF ALCINOUS—THE GAMES.
Now when the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, Alcinous
and Ulysses both rose, and Alcinous led the way t'the Phaeacian place
of assembly, which was near the ships. When they got there they sat
down side by side on a seat of polished stone, while Minerva took the
form of one of Alcinous' servants, and went round the town in order to
help Ulysses t'get home. She went up t'the citizens, man by man, and
said, "Aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians, come t'the
assembly all of you and listen t'the stranger wh'has just come off a
long voyage t'the house of King Alcinous; he looks like an immortal
god."
With these words she made them all want t'come, and they flocked to
the assembly till seats and standing room were alike crowded. Every one
was struck with the appearance of Ulysses, for Minerva had beautified
him about the head and shoulders, making him look taller and stouter
than he really was, that he might impress the Phaeacians favourably as
being a very remarkable man, and might come off well in the many trials
of skill t'which they would challenge him. Then, when they were got
together, Alcinous spoke:
"Hear me," said he, "aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians,
that I may speak even as I am minded. This stranger, whoever he may be,
has found his way t'my house from somewhere or other either East or
West. He wants an escort and wishes t'have the matter settled. Let us
then get one ready for him, as we have done for others before him;
indeed, n'one wh'ever yet came t'my house has been able t'complain
of me for not speeding on his way soon enough. Let us draw a ship into
the sea—one that has never yet made a voyage—and man her with tw'and
fifty of our smartest young sailors. Then when you have made fast your
oars each by his own seat, leave the ship and come t'my house to
prepare a feast.65 I will find you in everything. I am giving these
instructions t'the young men wh'will form the crew, for as regards
you aldermen and town councillors, you will join me in entertaining our
guest in the cloisters. I can take n'excuses, and we will have
Demodocus t'sing t'us; for there is n'bard like him whatever he may
choose t'sing about."

characters.name: Alcinous
characters.role: King of the Phaeacians, hosting Ulysses
characters.quote: Hear me, said he, aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians, that I may speak even as I am minded.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Stranger seeking help to return home
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Ulysses appears hopeful yet anxious as he seeks assistance from the Phaeacians to return home.

characters.name: Minerva
characters.role: Goddess aiding Ulysses in disguise
characters.quote: Aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians, come t'the assembly all of you and listen t'the stranger wh'has just come off a long voyage t'the house of King Alcinous; he looks like an immortal god.

scenes.title: Preparation for Games
scenes.summary: The Phaeacians prepare for athletic competitions after the feast.
scenes.text:
Alcinous then led the way, and the others followed after, while a
servant went t'fetch Demodocus. The fifty-tw'picked oarsmen went to
the sea shore as they had been told, and when they got there they drew
the ship int'the water, got her mast and sails inside her, bound the
oars t'the thole-pins with twisted thongs of leather, all in due
course, and spread the white sails aloft. They moored the vessel a
little way out from land, and then came on shore and went t'the house
of King Alcinous. The out houses,66 yards, and all the precincts were
filled with crowds of men in great multitudes both old and young; and
Alcinous killed them a dozen sheep, eight full grown pigs, and two
oxen. These they skinned and dressed s'as t'provide a magnificent
banquet.
A servant presently led in the famous bard Demodocus, whom the muse had
dearly loved, but t'whom she had given both good and evil, for though
she had endowed him with a divine gift of song, she had robbed him of
his eyesight. Pontonous set a seat for him among the guests, leaning it
up against a bearing-post. He hung the lyre for him on a peg over his
head, and showed him where he was t'feel for it with his hands. He
als'set a fair table with a basket of victuals by his side, and a cup
of wine from which he might drink whenever he was s'disposed.
The company then laid their hands upon the good things that were before
them, but as soon as they had had enough t'eat and drink, the muse
inspired Demodocus t'sing the feats of heroes, and more especially a
matter that was then in the mouths of all men, t'wit, the quarrel
between Ulysses and Achilles, and the fierce words that they heaped on
one another as they sat together at a banquet. But Agamemnon was glad
when he heard his chieftains quarrelling with one another, for Apollo
had foretold him this at Pyth'when he crossed the stone floor to
consult the oracle. Here was the beginning of the evil that by the will
of Jove fell both upon Danaans and Trojans.
Thus sang the bard, but Ulysses drew his purple mantle over his head
and covered his face, for he was ashamed t'let the Phaeacians see that
he was weeping. When the bard left off singing he wiped the tears from
his eyes, uncovered his face, and, taking his cup, made a
drink-offering t'the gods; but when the Phaeacians pressed Demodocus
t'sing further, for they delighted in his lays, then Ulysses again
drew his mantle over his head and wept bitterly. N'one noticed his
distress except Alcinous, wh'was sitting near him, and heard the heavy
sighs that he was heaving. S'he at once said, "Aldermen and town
councillors of the Phaeacians, we have had enough now, both of the
feast, and of the minstrelsy that is its due accompaniment; let us
proceed therefore t'the athletic sports, s'that our guest on his
return home may be able t'tell his friends how much we surpass all
other nations as boxers, wrestlers, jumpers, and runners."
With these words he led the way, and the others followed after. A

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: He is deeply affected by the bard's song, feeling shame and sorrow for his past.
characters.quote: Ulysses drew his purple mantle over his head and covered his face, for he was ashamed t'let the Phaeacians see that he was weeping.

characters.name: Demodocus
characters.role: He sings about the quarrel between Ulysses and Achilles, stirring emotions in Ulysses.
characters.quote: Thus sang the bard, but Ulysses drew his purple mantle over his head and covered his face, for he was ashamed t'let the Phaeacians see that he was weeping.

characters.name: Alcinous
characters.role: He notices Ulysses' distress and suggests moving on to athletic sports to alleviate the mood.
characters.quote: Aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians, we have had enough now, both of the feast, and of the minstrelsy that is its due accompaniment; let us proceed therefore t'the athletic sports.

scenes.title: Athletic Competitions
scenes.summary: Ulysses participates in the games, showcasing his strength.
scenes.text:
servant hung Demodocus's lyre on its peg for him, led him out of the
cloister, and set him on the same way as that along which all the chief
men of the Phaeacians were going t'see the sports; a crowd of several
thousands of people followed them, and there were many excellent
competitors for all the prizes. Acroneos, Ocyalus, Elatreus, Nauteus,
Prymneus, Anchialus, Eretmeus, Ponteus, Proreus, Thoon, Anabesineus,
and Amphialus son of Polyneus son of Tecton. There was als'Euryalus
son of Naubolus, wh'was like Mars himself, and was the best looking
man among the Phaeacians except Laodamas. Three sons of Alcinous,
Laodamas, Halios, and Clytoneus, competed also.
The foot races came first. The course was set out for them from the
starting post, and they raised a dust upon the plain as they all flew
forward at the same moment. Clytoneus came in first by a long way; he
left every one else behind him by the length of the furrow that a
couple of mules can plough in a fallow field.67 They then turned t'the
painful art of wrestling, and here Euryalus proved t'be the best man.
Amphialus excelled all the others in jumping, while at throwing the
disc there was n'one wh'could approach Elatreus. Alcinous's son
Laodamas was the best boxer, and he it was wh'presently said, when
they had all been diverted with the games, "Let us ask the stranger
whether he excels in any of these sports; he seems very powerfully
built; his thighs, calves, hands, and neck are of prodigious strength,
nor is he at all old, but he has suffered much lately, and there is
nothing like the sea for making havoc with a man, n'matter how strong
he is."
"You are quite right, Laodamas," replied Euryalus, "g'up t'your guest
and speak t'him about it yourself."
When Laodamas heard this he made his way int'the middle of the crowd
and said t'Ulysses, "I hope, Sir, that you will enter yourself for
some one or other of our competitions if you are skilled in any of
them—and you must have gone in for many a one before now. There is
nothing that does any one s'much credit all his life long as the
showing himself a proper man with his hands and feet. Have a try
therefore at something, and banish all sorrow from your mind. Your
return home will not be long delayed, for the ship is already drawn
int'the water, and the crew is found."
Ulysses answered, "Laodamas, why d'you taunt me in this way? my mind
is set rather on cares than contests; I have been through infinite
trouble, and am come among you now as a suppliant, praying your king
and people t'further me on my return home."
Then Euryalus reviled him outright and said, "I gather, then, that you
are unskilled in any of the many sports that men generally delight in.
I suppose you are one of those grasping traders that g'about in ships
as captains or merchants, and wh'think of nothing but of their outward
freights and homeward cargoes. There does not seem t'be much of the
athlete about you."
"For shame, Sir," answered Ulysses, fiercely, "you are an insolent
fellow—s'true is it that the gods d'not grace all men alike in
speech, person, and understanding. One man may be of weak presence, but
heaven has adorned this with such a good conversation that he charms
every one wh'sees him; his honeyed moderation carries his hearers with
him s'that he is leader in all assemblies of his fellows, and wherever
he goes he is looked up to. Another may be as handsome as a god, but
his good looks are not crowned with discretion. This is your case. No
god could make a finer looking fellow than you are, but you are a fool.
Your ill-judged remarks have made me exceedingly angry, and you are
quite mistaken, for I excel in a great many athletic exercises; indeed,
s'long as I had youth and strength, I was among the first athletes of
the age. Now, however, I am worn out by labour and sorrow, for I have
gone through much both on the field of battle and by the waves of the
weary sea; still, in spite of all this I will compete, for your taunts
have stung me t'the quick."
S'he hurried up without even taking his cloak off, and seized a disc,
larger, more massive and much heavier than those used by the Phaeacians
when disc-throwing among themselves.68 Then, swinging it back, he threw
it from his brawny hand, and it made a humming sound in the air as he
did so. The Phaeacians quailed beneath the rushing of its flight as it
sped gracefully from his hand, and flew beyond any mark that had been
made yet. Minerva, in the form of a man, came and marked the place
where it had fallen. "A blind man, Sir," said she, "could easily tell
your mark by groping for it—it is s'far ahead of any other. You may
make your mind easy about this contest, for n'Phaeacian can come near
t'such a throw as yours."
Ulysses was glad when he found he had a friend among the lookers-on, so
he began t'speak more pleasantly. "Young men," said he, "come up to
that throw if you can, and I will throw another disc as heavy or even
heavier. If anyone wants t'have a bout with me let him come on, for I
am exceedingly angry; I will box, wrestle, or run, I d'not care what
it is, with any man of you all except Laodamas, but not with him
because I am his guest, and one cannot compete with one's own personal
friend. At least I d'not think it a prudent or a sensible thing for a
guest t'challenge his host's family at any game, especially when he is
in a foreign country. He will cut the ground from under his own feet if
he does; but I make n'exception as regards any one else, for I want to
have the matter out and know which is the best man. I am a good hand at
every kind of athletic sport known among mankind. I am an excellent
archer. In battle I am always the first t'bring a man down with my
arrow, n'matter how many more are taking aim at him alongside of me.
Philoctetes was the only man wh'could shoot better than I could when
we Achaeans were before Troy and in practice. I far excel every one
else in the whole world, of those wh'still eat bread upon the face of
the earth, but I should not like t'shoot against the mighty dead, such
as Hercules, or Eurytus the Oechalian—men wh'could shoot against the
gods themselves. This in fact was how Eurytus came prematurely by his
end, for Apoll'was angry with him and killed him because he challenged
him as an archer. I can throw a dart farther than any one else can
shoot an arrow. Running is the only point in respect of which I am
afraid some of the Phaeacians might beat me, for I have been brought
down very low at sea; my provisions ran short, and therefore I am still
weak."

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: A weary traveler seeking to prove his strength
characters.quote: For shame, Sir, answered Ulysses, fiercely, you are an insolent fellow—s'true is it that the gods d'not grace all men alike in speech, person, and understanding.

characters.name: Laodamas
characters.role: Encouraging Ulysses to compete in the games
characters.quote: Let us ask the stranger whether he excels in any of these sports; he seems very powerfully built; his thighs, calves, hands, and neck are of prodigious strength.

characters.name: Euryalus
characters.role: Challenging Ulysses' athletic abilities
characters.quote: I gather, then, that you are unskilled in any of the many sports that men generally delight in.

scenes.title: Demodocus's Song
scenes.summary: Demodocus sings of the Trojan War, moving Ulysses to tears.
scenes.text:
They all held their peace except King Alcinous, wh'began, "Sir, we
have had much pleasure in hearing all that you have told us, from which
I understand that you are willing t'show your prowess, as having been
displeased with some insolent remarks that have been made t'you by one
of our athletes, and which could never have been uttered by any one who
knows how t'talk with propriety. I hope you will apprehend my meaning,
and will explain t'any one of your chief men wh'may be dining with
yourself and your family when you get home, that we have an hereditary
aptitude for accomplishments of all kinds. We are not particularly
remarkable for our boxing, nor yet as wrestlers, but we are singularly
fleet of foot and are excellent sailors. We are extremely fond of good
dinners, music, and dancing; we als'like frequent changes of linen,
warm baths, and good beds, s'now, please, some of you wh'are the best
dancers set about dancing, that our guest on his return home may be
able t'tell his friends how much we surpass all other nations as
sailors, runners, dancers, and minstrels. Demodocus has left his lyre
at my house, s'run some one or other of you and fetch it for him."
On this a servant hurried off t'bring the lyre from the king's house,
and the nine men wh'had been chosen as stewards stood forward. It was
their business t'manage everything connected with the sports, s'they
made the ground smooth and marked a wide space for the dancers.
Presently the servant came back with Demodocus's lyre, and he took his
place in the midst of them, whereon the best young dancers in the town
began t'foot and trip it s'nimbly that Ulysses was delighted with the
merry twinkling of their feet.
Meanwhile the bard began t'sing the loves of Mars and Venus, and how
they first began their intrigue in the house of Vulcan. Mars made Venus
many presents, and defiled King Vulcan's marriage bed, s'the sun, who
saw what they were about, told Vulcan. Vulcan was very angry when he
heard such dreadful news, s'he went t'his smithy brooding mischief,
got his great anvil int'its place, and began t'forge some chains
which none could either unloose or break, s'that they might stay there
in that place.69 When he had finished his snare he went int'his
bedroom and festooned the bed-posts all over with chains like cobwebs;
he als'let many hang down from the great beam of the ceiling. Not even
a god could see them s'fine and subtle were they. As soon as he had
spread the chains all over the bed, he made as though he were setting
out for the fair state of Lemnos, which of all places in the world was
the one he was most fond of. But Mars kept n'blind look out, and as
soon as he saw him start, hurried off t'his house, burning with love
for Venus.
Now Venus was just come in from a visit t'her father Jove, and was
about sitting down when Mars came inside the house, and said as he took
her hand in his own, "Let us g't'the couch of Vulcan: he is not at
home, but is gone off t'Lemnos among the Sintians, whose speech is
barbarous."
She was nothing loth, s'they went t'the couch t'take their rest,
whereon they were caught in the toils which cunning Vulcan had spread
for them, and could neither get up nor stir hand or foot, but found too
late that they were in a trap. Then Vulcan came up t'them, for he had
turned back before reaching Lemnos, when his scout the sun told him
what was going on. He was in a furious passion, and stood in the
vestibule making a dreadful noise as he shouted t'all the gods.
"Father Jove," he cried, "and all you other blessed gods wh'live for
ever, come here and see the ridiculous and disgraceful sight that I
will show you. Jove's daughter Venus is always dishonouring me because
I am lame. She is in love with Mars, wh'is handsome and clean built,
whereas I am a cripple—but my parents are t'blame for that, not I;
they ought never t'have begotten me. Come and see the pair together
asleep on my bed. It makes me furious t'look at them. They are very
fond of one another, but I d'not think they will lie there longer than
they can help, nor d'I think that they will sleep much; there,
however, they shall stay till her father has repaid me the sum I gave
him for his baggage of a daughter, wh'is fair but not honest."
On this the gods gathered t'the house of Vulcan. Earth-encircling
Neptune came, and Mercury the bringer of luck, and King Apollo, but the
goddesses staid at home all of them for shame. Then the givers of all
good things stood in the doorway, and the blessed gods roared with
inextinguishable laughter, as they saw how cunning Vulcan had been,
whereon one would turn towards his neighbour saying:
"Ill deeds d'not prosper, and the weak confound the strong. See how
limping Vulcan, lame as he is, has caught Mars wh'is the fleetest god
in heaven; and now Mars will be cast in heavy damages."
Thus did they converse, but King Apoll'said t'Mercury, "Messenger
Mercury, giver of good things, you would not care how strong the chains
were, would you, if you could sleep with Venus?"
"King Apollo," answered Mercury, "I only wish I might get the chance,
though there were three times as many chains—and you might look on, all
of you, gods and goddesses, but I would sleep with her if I could."
The immortal gods burst out laughing as they heard him, but Neptune
took it all seriously, and kept on imploring Vulcan t'set Mars free
again. "Let him go," he cried, "and I will undertake, as you require,
that he shall pay you all the damages that are held reasonable among
the immortal gods."
"D'not," replied Vulcan, "ask me t'd'this; a bad man's bond is bad
security; what remedy could I enforce against you if Mars should go
away and leave his debts behind him along with his chains?"
"Vulcan," said Neptune, "if Mars goes away without paying his damages,
I will pay you myself." S'Vulcan answered, "In this case I cannot and
must not refuse you."
Thereon he loosed the bonds that bound them, and as soon as they were
free they scampered off, Mars t'Thrace and laughter-loving Venus to
Cyprus and t'Paphos, where is her grove and her altar fragrant with
burnt offerings. Here the Graces bathed her, and anointed her with oil
of ambrosia such as the immortal gods make use of, and they clothed her
in raiment of the most enchanting beauty.
Thus sang the bard, and both Ulysses and the seafaring Phaeacians were
charmed as they heard him.
Then Alcinous told Laodamas and Halius t'dance alone, for there was no
one t'compete with them. S'they took a red ball which Polybus had
made for them, and one of them bent himself backwards and threw it up
towards the clouds, while the other jumped from off the ground and
caught it with ease before it came down again. When they had done
throwing the ball straight up int'the air they began t'dance, and at
the same time kept on throwing it backwards and forwards t'one
another, while all the young men in the ring applauded and made a great
stamping with their feet. Then Ulysses said:
"King Alcinous, you said your people were the nimblest dancers in the
world, and indeed they have proved themselves t'be so. I was
astonished as I saw them."
The king was delighted at this, and exclaimed t'the Phaeacians,
"Aldermen and town councillors, our guest seems t'be a person of
singular judgement; let us give him such proof of our hospitality as he
may reasonably expect. There are twelve chief men among you, and
counting myself there are thirteen; contribute, each of you, a clean
cloak, a shirt, and a talent of fine gold; let us give him all this in
a lump down at once, s'that when he gets his supper he may d's'with
a light heart. As for Euryalus he will have t'make a formal apology
and a present too, for he has been rude."
Thus did he speak. The others all of them applauded his saying, and
sent their servants t'fetch the presents. Then Euryalus said, "King
Alcinous, I will give the stranger all the satisfaction you require. He
shall have my sword, which is of bronze, all but the hilt, which is of
silver. I will als'give him the scabbard of newly sawn ivory into
which it fits. It will be worth a great deal t'him."
As he spoke he placed the sword in the hands of Ulysses and said, "Good
luck t'you, father stranger; if anything has been said amiss may the
winds blow it away with them, and may heaven grant you a safe return,
for I understand you have been long away from home, and have gone
through much hardship."
T'which Ulysses answered, "Good luck t'you to'my friend, and may the
gods grant you every happiness. I hope you will not miss the sword you
have given me along with your apology."
With these words he girded the sword about his shoulders and towards
sundown the presents began t'make their appearance, as the servants of
the donors kept bringing them t'the house of King Alcinous; here his
sons received them, and placed them under their mother's charge. Then
Alcinous led the way t'the house and bade his guests take their seats.
"Wife," said he, turning t'Queen Arete, "Go, fetch the best chest we
have, and put a clean cloak and shirt in it. Also, set a copper on the
fire and heat some water; our guest will take a warm bath; see als'to
the careful packing of the presents that the noble Phaeacians have made
him; he will thus better enjoy both his supper and the singing that
will follow. I shall myself give him this golden goblet—which is of
exquisite workmanship—that he may be reminded of me for the rest of his
life whenever he makes a drink offering t'Jove, or t'any of the
gods."70
Then Arete told her maids t'set a large tripod upon the fire as fast
as they could, whereon they set a tripod full of bath water on t'a
clear fire; they threw on sticks t'make it blaze, and the water became
hot as the flame played about the belly of the tripod.71 Meanwhile
Arete brought a magnificent chest from her own room, and inside it she
packed all the beautiful presents of gold and raiment which the
Phaeacians had brought. Lastly she added a cloak and a good shirt from
Alcinous, and said t'Ulysses:
"See t'the lid yourself, and have the whole bound round at once, for
fear any one should rob you by the way when you are asleep in your
ship." 72
When Ulysses heard this he put the lid on the chest and made it fast
with a bond that Circe had taught him. He had done s'before an upper
servant told him t'come t'the bath and wash himself. He was very glad
of a warm bath, for he had had n'one t'wait upon him ever since he
left the house of Calypso, wh'as long as he remained with her had
taken as good care of him as though he had been a god. When the
servants had done washing and anointing him with oil, and had given him
a clean cloak and shirt, he left the bath room and joined the guests
wh'were sitting over their wine. Lovely Nausicaa stood by one of the
bearing-posts supporting the roof of the cloister, and admired him as
she saw him pass. "Farewell stranger," said she, "d'not forget me when
you are safe at home again, for it is t'me first that you owe a ransom
for having saved your life."
And Ulysses said, "Nausicaa, daughter of great Alcinous, may Jove the
mighty husband of Juno, grant that I may reach my home; s'shall I
bless you as my guardian angel all my days, for it was you wh'saved
me."
When he had said this, he seated himself beside Alcinous. Supper was
then served, and the wine was mixed for drinking. A servant led in the
favourite bard Demodocus, and set him in the midst of the company, near
one of the bearing-posts supporting the cloister, that he might lean
against it. Then Ulysses cut off a piece of roast pork with plenty of
fat (for there was abundance left on the joint) and said t'a servant,
"Take this piece of pork over t'Demodocus and tell him t'eat it; for
all the pain his lays may cause me I will salute him none the less;
bards are honoured and respected throughout the world, for the muse
teaches them their songs and loves them."
The servant carried the pork in his fingers over t'Demodocus, wh'took
it and was very much pleased. They then laid their hands on the good
things that were before them, and as soon as they had had t'eat and
drink, Ulysses said t'Demodocus, "Demodocus, there is n'one in the
world whom I admire more than I d'you. You must have studied under the
Muse, Jove's daughter, and under Apollo, s'accurately d'you sing the
return of the Achaeans with all their sufferings and adventures. If you
were not there yourself, you must have heard it all from some one who
was. Now, however, change your song and tell us of the wooden horse
which Epeus made with the assistance of Minerva, and which Ulysses got
by stratagem int'the fort of Troy after freighting it with the men who
afterwards sacked the city. If you will sing this tale aright I will
tell all the world how magnificently heaven has endowed you."
The bard inspired of heaven took up the story at the point where some
of the Argives set fire t'their tents and sailed away while others,
hidden within the horse,73 were waiting with Ulysses in the Trojan
place of assembly. For the Trojans themselves had drawn the horse into
their fortress, and it stood there while they sat in council round it,
and were in three minds as t'what they should do. Some were for
breaking it up then and there; others would have it dragged t'the top
of the rock on which the fortress stood, and then thrown down the
precipice; while yet others were for letting it remain as an offering
and propitiation for the gods. And this was how they settled it in the
end, for the city was doomed when it took in that horse, within which
were all the bravest of the Argives waiting t'bring death and
destruction on the Trojans. Anon he sang how the sons of the Achaeans
issued from the horse, and sacked the town, breaking out from their
ambuscade. He sang how they overran the city hither and thither and
ravaged it, and how Ulysses went raging like Mars along with Menelaus
t'the house of Deiphobus. It was there that the fight raged most
furiously, nevertheless by Minerva's help he was victorious.
All this he told, but Ulysses was overcome as he heard him, and his
cheeks were wet with tears. He wept as a woman weeps when she throws
herself on the body of her husband wh'has fallen before his own city
and people, fighting bravely in defence of his home and children. She
screams aloud and flings her arms about him as he lies gasping for
breath and dying, but her enemies beat her from behind about the back
and shoulders, and carry her off int'slavery, t'a life of labour and
sorrow, and the beauty fades from her cheeks—even s'piteously did
Ulysses weep, but none of those present perceived his tears except
Alcinous, wh'was sitting near him, and could hear the sobs and sighs

scenes.title: Gifts and Farewell
scenes.summary: Alcinous and the Phaeacians present gifts to Ulysses before his departure.
scenes.text:
that he was heaving. The king, therefore, at once rose and said:
"Aldermen and town councillors of the Phaeacians, let Demodocus cease
his song, for there are those present wh'd'not seem t'like it. From
the moment that we had done supper and Demodocus began t'sing, our
guest has been all the time groaning and lamenting. He is evidently in
great trouble, s'let the bard leave off, that we may all enjoy
ourselves, hosts and guest alike. This will be much more as it should
be, for all these festivities, with the escort and the presents that we
are making with s'much good will are wholly in his honour, and any one
with even a moderate amount of right feeling knows that he ought to
treat a guest and a suppliant as though he were his own brother.
"Therefore, Sir, d'you on your part affect n'more concealment nor
reserve in the matter about which I shall ask you; it will be more
polite in you t'give me a plain answer; tell me the name by which your
father and mother over yonder used t'call you, and by which you were
known among your neighbours and fellow-citizens. There is n'one,
neither rich nor poor, wh'is absolutely without any name whatever, for
people's fathers and mothers give them names as soon as they are born.
Tell me als'your country, nation, and city, that our ships may shape
their purpose accordingly and take you there. For the Phaeacians have
n'pilots; their vessels have n'rudders as those of other nations
have, but the ships themselves understand what it is that we are
thinking about and want; they know all the cities and countries in the
whole world, and can traverse the sea just as well even when it is
covered with mist and cloud, s'that there is n'danger of being
wrecked or coming t'any harm. Still I d'remember hearing my father
say that Neptune was angry with us for being to'easy-going in the
matter of giving people escorts. He said that one of these days he
should wreck a ship of ours as it was returning from having escorted
some one,74 and bury our city under a high mountain. This is what my
father used t'say, but whether the god will carry out his threat or no
is a matter which he will decide for himself.
"And now, tell me and tell me true. Where have you been wandering, and
in what countries have you travelled? Tell us of the peoples
themselves, and of their cities—wh'were hostile, savage and
uncivilised, and who, on the other hand, hospitable and humane. Tell us
als'why you are made s'unhappy on hearing about the return of the
Argive Danaans from Troy. The gods arranged all this, and sent them
their misfortunes in order that future generations might have something
t'sing about. Did you lose some brave kinsman of your wife's when you
were before Troy? a son-in-law or father-in-law—which are the nearest
relations a man has outside his own flesh and blood? or was it some
brave and kindly-natured comrade—for a good friend is as dear t'a man
as his own brother?"

characters.name: Alcinous
characters.role: Concerned about the guest's distress

characters.role: Bard whose song causes distress

characters.name: The Guest
characters.role: Distressed by the song and memories

scenes.title: Ulysses Begins His Tale
scenes.summary: Ulysses introduces himself and begins recounting his adventures.
scenes.text:
ULYSSES DECLARES HIMSELF AND BEGINS HIS STORY—-THE CICONS, LOTOPHAGI,
AND CYCLOPES.
And Ulysses answered, "King Alcinous, it is a good thing t'hear a bard
with such a divine voice as this man has. There is nothing better or
more delightful than when a whole people make merry together, with the
guests sitting orderly t'listen, while the table is loaded with bread
and meats, and the cup-bearer draws wine and fills his cup for every
man. This is indeed as fair a sight as a man can see. Now, however,
since you are inclined t'ask the story of my sorrows, and rekindle my
own sad memories in respect of them, I d'not know how t'begin, nor
yet how t'continue and conclude my tale, for the hand of heaven has
been laid heavily upon me.
"Firstly, then, I will tell you my name that you to'may know it, and
one day, if I outlive this time of sorrow, may become my guests though
I live s'far away from all of you. I am Ulysses son of Laertes,
renowned among mankind for all manner of subtlety, s'that my fame
ascends t'heaven. I live in Ithaca, where there is a high mountain
called Neritum, covered with forests; and not far from it there is a
group of islands very near t'one another—Dulichium, Same, and the
wooded island of Zacynthus. It lies squat on the horizon, all highest
up in the sea towards the sunset, while the others lie away from it
towards dawn.75 It is a rugged island, but it breeds brave men, and my
eyes know none that they better love t'look upon. The goddess Calypso
kept me with her in her cave, and wanted me t'marry her, as did also
the cunning Aeaean goddess Circe; but they could neither of them
persuade me, for there is nothing dearer t'a man than his own country
and his parents, and however splendid a home he may have in a foreign
country, if it be far from father or mother, he does not care about it.
Now, however, I will tell you of the many hazardous adventures which by
Jove's will I met with on my return from Troy.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Protagonist recounting his adventures
characters.quote: I am Ulysses son of Laertes, renowned among mankind for all manner of subtlety, s'that my fame ascends t'heaven.

characters.name: Alcinous
characters.role: Listener and host encouraging Ulysses
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: King Alcinous shows curiosity and support for Ulysses' story, encouraging him to share his experiences.

scenes.title: The Cicones Encounter
scenes.summary: Ulysses describes the battle with the Cicones after sacking their city.
scenes.text:
"When I had set sail thence the wind took me first t'Ismarus, which is
the city of the Cicons. There I sacked the town and put the people to
the sword. We took their wives and als'much booty, which we divided
equitably amongst us, s'that none might have reason t'complain. I
then said that we had better make off at once, but my men very
foolishly would not obey me, s'they staid there drinking much wine and
killing great numbers of sheep and oxen on the sea shore. Meanwhile the
Cicons cried out for help t'other Cicons wh'lived inland. These were
more in number, and stronger, and they were more skilled in the art of
war, for they could fight, either from chariots or on foot as the
occasion served; in the morning, therefore, they came as thick as
leaves and bloom in summer, and the hand of heaven was against us, so
that we were hard pressed. They set the battle in array near the ships,
and the hosts aimed their bronze-shod spears at one another.76 S'long
as the day waxed and it was still morning, we held our own against
them, though they were more in number than we; but as the sun went
down, towards the time when men loose their oxen, the Cicons got the
better of us, and we lost half a dozen men from every ship we had; so
we got away with those that were left.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Leader of the crew, recounting the battle
characters.quote: I then said that we had better make off at once, but my men very foolishly would not obey me

characters.name: Cicons
characters.role: Defenders of their city, fighting back against the invaders
characters.quote: the Cicons cried out for help t'other Cicons wh'lived inland

scenes.title: The Lotus-Eaters
scenes.summary: Ulysses recounts the encounter with the Lotus-Eaters and their enchanting food.
scenes.text:
"Thence we sailed onward with sorrow in our hearts, but glad t'have
escaped death though we had lost our comrades, nor did we leave till we
had thrice invoked each one of the poor fellows wh'had perished by the
hands of the Cicons. Then Jove raised the North wind against us till it
blew a hurricane, s'that land and sky were hidden in thick clouds, and
night sprang forth out of the heavens. We let the ships run before the
gale, but the force of the wind tore our sails t'tatters, s'we took
them down for fear of shipwreck, and rowed our hardest towards the
land. There we lay tw'days and tw'nights suffering much alike from
toil and distress of mind, but on the morning of the third day we again
raised our masts, set sail, and took our places, letting the wind and
steersmen direct our ship. I should have got home at that time unharmed
had not the North wind and the currents been against me as I was
doubling Cape Malea, and set me off my course hard by the island of
Cythera.
"I was driven thence by foul winds for a space of nine days upon the
sea, but on the tenth day we reached the land of the Lotus-eaters, who
live on a food that comes from a kind of flower. Here we landed t'take
in fresh water, and our crews got their mid-day meal on the shore near
the ships. When they had eaten and drunk I sent tw'of my company to
see what manner of men the people of the place might be, and they had a
third man under them. They started at once, and went about among the
Lotus-eaters, wh'did them n'hurt, but gave them t'eat of the lotus,
which was s'delicious that those wh'ate of it left off caring about
home, and did not even want t'g'back and say what had happened to
them, but were for staying and munching lotus77 with the Lotus-eaters
without thinking further of their return; nevertheless, though they
wept bitterly I forced them back t'the ships and made them fast under
the benches. Then I told the rest t'g'on board at once, lest any of
them should taste of the lotus and leave off wanting t'get home, so
they took their places and smote the grey sea with their oars.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Leader trying to save his men
characters.quote: I forced them back t'the ships and made them fast under the benches.

characters.name: Lotus-eaters
characters.role: Tempting Odysseus's crew with lotus
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The Lotus-eaters offered the lotus to Odysseus's men, showing no concern for their desire to return home.

characters.name: Crew Members
characters.role: Men tempted by the lotus
characters.quote: they wept bitterly

scenes.title: The Cyclopes' Land
scenes.summary: Ulysses describes the land of the Cyclopes and their way of life.
scenes.text:
"We sailed hence, always in much distress, till we came t'the land of
the lawless and inhuman Cyclopes. Now the Cyclopes neither plant nor
plough, but trust in providence, and live on such wheat, barley, and
grapes as grow wild without any kind of tillage, and their wild grapes
yield them wine as the sun and the rain may grow them. They have no
laws nor assemblies of the people, but live in caves on the tops of
high mountains; each is lord and master in his family, and they take no
account of their neighbours.
"Now off their harbour there lies a wooded and fertile island not quite
close t'the land of the Cyclopes, but still not far. It is over-run
with wild goats, that breed there in great numbers and are never
disturbed by foot of man; for sportsmen—wh'as a rule will suffer so
much hardship in forest or among mountain precipices—d'not g'there,
nor yet again is it ever ploughed or fed down, but it lies a wilderness
untilled and unsown from year t'year, and has n'living thing upon it
but only goats. For the Cyclopes have n'ships, nor yet shipwrights who
could make ships for them; they cannot therefore g'from city t'city,
or sail over the sea t'one another's country as people wh'have ships
can do; if they had had these they would have colonised the island,78
for it is a very good one, and would yield everything in due season.
There are meadows that in some places come right down t'the sea shore,
well watered and full of luscious grass; grapes would d'there
excellently; there is level land for ploughing, and it would always
yield heavily at harvest time, for the soil is deep. There is a good
harbour where n'cables are wanted, nor yet anchors, nor need a ship be
moored, but all one has t'd'is t'beach one's vessel and stay there
till the wind becomes fair for putting out t'sea again. At the head of
the harbour there is a spring of clear water coming out of a cave, and

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Narrator describing the Cyclopes
characters.quote: Now the Cyclopes neither plant nor plough, but trust in providence, and live on such wheat, barley, and grapes as grow wild without any kind of tillage.

characters.name: Cyclopes
characters.role: Described as lawless and inhuman
characters.quote: They have no laws nor assemblies of the people, but live in caves on the tops of high mountains; each is lord and master in his family, and they take no account of their neighbours.

scenes.title: The Arrival at the Cave
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men arrive at the cave of Polyphemus, the Cyclops.
scenes.text:
there are poplars growing all round it.
"Here we entered, but s'dark was the night that some god must have
brought us in, for there was nothing whatever t'be seen. A thick mist
hung all round our ships;79 the moon was hidden behind a mass of clouds
s'that n'one could have seen the island if he had looked for it, nor
were there any breakers t'tell us we were close in shore before we
found ourselves upon the land itself; when, however, we had beached the
ships, we took down the sails, went ashore and camped upon the beach
till daybreak.
"When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn appeared, we admired the
island and wandered all over it, while the nymphs Jove's daughters
roused the wild goats that we might get some meat for our dinner. On
this we fetched our spears and bows and arrows from the ships, and
dividing ourselves int'three bands began t'shoot the goats. Heaven
sent us excellent sport; I had twelve ships with me, and each ship got
nine goats, while my own ship had ten; thus through the livelong day to
the going down of the sun we ate and drank our fill, and we had plenty
of wine left, for each one of us had taken many jars full when we
sacked the city of the Cicons, and this had not yet run out. While we
were feasting we kept turning our eyes towards the land of the
Cyclopes, which was hard by, and saw the smoke of their stubble fires.
We could almost fancy we heard their voices and the bleating of their
sheep and goats, but when the sun went down and it came on dark, we
camped down upon the beach, and next morning I called a council.
"'Stay here, my brave fellows,' said I, 'all the rest of you, while I
g'with my ship and exploit these people myself: I want t'see if they
are uncivilised savages, or a hospitable and humane race.'
"I went on board, bidding my men t'd's'als'and loose the hawsers;
s'they took their places and smote the grey sea with their oars. When
we got t'the land, which was not far, there, on the face of a cliff
near the sea, we saw a great cave overhung with laurels. It was a
station for a great many sheep and goats, and outside there was a large
yard, with a high wall round it made of stones built int'the ground
and of trees both pine and oak. This was the abode of a huge monster
wh'was then away from home shepherding his flocks. He would have
nothing t'd'with other people, but led the life of an outlaw. He was
a horrid creature, not like a human being at all, but resembling rather
some crag that stands out boldly against the sky on the top of a high

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Leader of the expedition, seeking to explore the island and assess its inhabitants
characters.quote: 'Stay here, my brave fellows,' said I, 'all the rest of you, while I g'with my ship and exploit these people myself: I want t'see if they are uncivilised savages, or a hospitable and humane race.'

characters.name: Polyphemus
characters.role: Anticipated antagonist, a monstrous figure representing danger
characters.quote: He was a horrid creature, not like a human being at all, but resembling rather some crag that stands out boldly against the sky on the top of a high

scenes.title: The Cyclops' Return
scenes.summary: The Cyclops returns home, and Ulysses and his men hide from him.
scenes.text:
mountain.
"I told my men t'draw the ship ashore, and stay where they were, all
but the twelve best among them, wh'were t'g'along with myself. I
als'took a goatskin of sweet black wine which had been given me by
Maron, son of Euanthes, wh'was priest of Apoll'the patron god of
Ismarus, and lived within the wooded precincts of the temple. When we
were sacking the city we respected him, and spared his life, as also
his wife and child; s'he made me some presents of great value—seven
talents of fine gold, and a bowl of silver, with twelve jars of sweet
wine, unblended, and of the most exquisite flavour. Not a man nor maid
in the house knew about it, but only himself, his wife, and one
housekeeper: when he drank it he mixed twenty parts of water t'one of
wine, and yet the fragrance from the mixing-bowl was s'exquisite that
it was impossible t'refrain from drinking. I filled a large skin with
this wine, and took a wallet full of provisions with me, for my mind
misgave me that I might have t'deal with some savage wh'would be of
great strength, and would respect neither right nor law.
"We soon reached his cave, but he was out shepherding, s'we went
inside and took stock of all that we could see. His cheese-racks were
loaded with cheeses, and he had more lambs and kids than his pens could
hold. They were kept in separate flocks; first there were the hoggets,
then the oldest of the younger lambs and lastly the very young ones80
all kept apart from one another; as for his dairy, all the vessels,
bowls, and milk pails int'which he milked, were swimming with whey.
When they saw all this, my men begged me t'let them first steal some
cheeses, and make off with them t'the ship; they would then return,
drive down the lambs and kids, put them on board and sail away with
them. It would have been indeed better if we had done s'but I would
not listen t'them, for I wanted t'see the owner himself, in the hope
that he might give me a present. When, however, we saw him my poor men
found him ill t'deal with.
"We lit a fire, offered some of the cheeses in sacrifice, ate others of
them, and then sat waiting till the Cyclops should come in with his
sheep. When he came, he brought in with him a huge load of dry firewood
t'light the fire for his supper, and this he flung with such a noise
on t'the floor of his cave that we hid ourselves for fear at the far
end of the cavern. Meanwhile he drove all the ewes inside, as well as
the she-goats that he was going t'milk, leaving the males, both rams
and he-goats, outside in the yards. Then he rolled a huge stone t'the
mouth of the cave—s'huge that tw'and twenty strong four-wheeled
waggons would not be enough t'draw it from its place against the
doorway. When he had s'done he sat down and milked his ewes and goats,
all in due course, and then let each of them have her own young. He
curdled half the milk and set it aside in wicker strainers, but the
other half he poured int'bowls that he might drink it for his supper.
When he had got through with all his work, he lit the fire, and then
caught sight of us, whereon he said:
"'Strangers, wh'are you? Where d'sail from? Are you traders, or do
you sail the sea as rovers, with your hands against every man, and
every man's hand against you?'
"We were frightened out of our senses by his loud voice and monstrous
form, but I managed t'say, 'We are Achaeans on our way home from Troy,
but by the will of Jove, and stress of weather, we have been driven far
out of our course. We are the people of Agamemnon, son of Atreus, who
has won infinite renown throughout the whole world, by sacking s'great
a city and killing s'many people. We therefore humbly pray you t'show
us some hospitality, and otherwise make us such presents as visitors
may reasonably expect. May your excellency fear the wrath of heaven,
for we are your suppliants, and Jove takes all respectable travellers
under his protection, for he is the avenger of all suppliants and
foreigners in distress.'
"T'this he gave me but a pitiless answer, 'Stranger,' said he, 'you
are a fool, or else you know nothing of this country. Talk t'me,
indeed, about fearing the gods or shunning their anger? We Cyclopes do
not care about Jove or any of your blessed gods, for we are ever so
much stronger than they. I shall not spare either yourself or your
companions out of any regard for Jove, unless I am in the humour for
doing so. And now tell me where you made your ship fast when you came
on shore. Was it round the point, or is she lying straight off the
land?'
"He said this t'draw me out, but I was to'cunning t'be caught in
that way, s'I answered with a lie; 'Neptune,' said I, 'sent my ship on
t'the rocks at the far end of your country, and wrecked it. We were
driven on t'them from the open sea, but I and those wh'are with me
escaped the jaws of death.'
"The cruel wretch vouchsafed me not one word of answer, but with a
sudden clutch he gripped up tw'of my men at once and dashed them down
upon the ground as though they had been puppies. Their brains were shed
upon the ground, and the earth was wet with their blood. Then he tore
them limb from limb and supped upon them. He gobbled them up like a
lion in the wilderness, flesh, bones, marrow, and entrails, without
leaving anything uneaten. As for us, we wept and lifted up our hands to
heaven on seeing such a horrid sight, for we did not know what else to
do; but when the Cyclops had filled his huge paunch, and had washed
down his meal of human flesh with a drink of neat milk, he stretched
himself full length upon the ground among his sheep, and went t'sleep.

characters.role: Antagonist, brutal and dismissive of the Achaeans

scenes.title: The Blinding of Polyphemus
scenes.summary: Ulysses devises a plan to blind the Cyclops and escape.
scenes.text:
I was at first inclined t'seize my sword, draw it, and drive it into
his vitals, but I reflected that if I did we should all certainly be
lost, for we should never be able t'shift the stone which the monster
had put in front of the door. S'we stayed sobbing and sighing where we
were till morning came.
"When the child of morning, rosy-fingered dawn, appeared, he again lit
his fire, milked his goats and ewes, all quite rightly, and then let
each have her own young one; as soon as he had got through with all his
work, he clutched up tw'more of my men, and began eating them for his
morning's meal. Presently, with the utmost ease, he rolled the stone
away from the door and drove out his sheep, but he at once put it back
again—as easily as though he were merely clapping the lid on t'a
quiver full of arrows. As soon as he had done s'he shouted, and cried
'Shoo, shoo,' after his sheep t'drive them on t'the mountain; s'I
was left t'scheme some way of taking my revenge and covering myself
with glory.
"In the end I deemed it would be the best plan t'd'as follows: The
Cyclops had a great club which was lying near one of the sheep pens; it
was of green olive wood, and he had cut it intending t'use it for a
staff as soon as it should be dry. It was s'huge that we could only
compare it t'the mast of a twenty-oared merchant vessel of large
burden, and able t'venture out int'open sea. I went up t'this club
and cut off about six feet of it; I then gave this piece t'the men and
told them t'fine it evenly off at one end, which they proceeded t'do,
and lastly I brought it t'a point myself, charring the end in the fire
t'make it harder. When I had done this I hid it under dung, which was
lying about all over the cave, and told the men t'cast lots which of
them should venture along with myself t'lift it and bore it int'the
monster's eye while he was asleep. The lot fell upon the very four whom
I should have chosen, and I myself made five. In the evening the wretch
came back from shepherding, and drove his flocks int'the cave—this
time driving them all inside, and not leaving any in the yards; I
suppose some fancy must have taken him, or a god must have prompted him
t'd'so. As soon as he had put the stone back t'its place against the
door, he sat down, milked his ewes and his goats all quite rightly, and
then let each have her own young one; when he had got through with all
this work, he gripped up tw'more of my men, and made his supper off
them. S'I went up t'him with an ivy-wood bowl of black wine in my
hands:
"'Look here, Cyclops,' said I, you have been eating a great deal of
man's flesh, s'take this and drink some wine, that you may see what
kind of liquor we had on board my ship. I was bringing it t'you as a
drink-offering, in the hope that you would take compassion upon me and
further me on my way home, whereas all you d'is t'g'on ramping and
raving most intolerably. You ought t'be ashamed of yourself; how can
you expect people t'come see you any more if you treat them in this
way?'
"He then took the cup and drank. He was s'delighted with the taste of
the wine that he begged me for another bowl full. 'Be s'kind,' he
said, 'as t'give me some more, and tell me your name at once. I want
t'make you a present that you will be glad t'have. We have wine even
in this country, for our soil grows grapes and the sun ripens them, but
this drinks like Nectar and Ambrosia all in one.'
"I then gave him some more; three times did I fill the bowl for him,
and three times did he drain it without thought or heed; then, when I
saw that the wine had got int'his head, I said t'him as plausibly as
I could: 'Cyclops, you ask my name and I will tell it you; give me,
therefore, the present you promised me; my name is Noman; this is what
my father and mother and my friends have always called me.'
"But the cruel wretch said, 'Then I will eat all Noman's comrades
before Noman himself, and will keep Noman for the last. This is the
present that I will make him.'
"As he spoke he reeled, and fell sprawling face upwards on the ground.
His great neck hung heavily backwards and a deep sleep took hold upon
him. Presently he turned sick, and threw up both wine and the gobbets
of human flesh on which he had been gorging, for he was very drunk.
Then I thrust the beam of wood far int'the embers t'heat it, and
encouraged my men lest any of them should turn faint-hearted. When the
wood, green though it was, was about t'blaze, I drew it out of the
fire glowing with heat, and my men gathered round me, for heaven had
filled their hearts with courage. We drove the sharp end of the beam
int'the monster's eye, and bearing upon it with all my weight I kept
turning it round and round as though I were boring a hole in a ship's
plank with an auger, which tw'men with a wheel and strap can keep on
turning as long as they choose. Even thus did we bore the red hot beam
int'his eye, till the boiling blood bubbled all over it as we worked
it round and round, s'that the steam from the burning eyeball scalded
his eyelids and eyebrows, and the roots of the eye sputtered in the
fire. As a blacksmith plunges an axe or hatchet int'cold water to
temper it—for it is this that gives strength t'the iron—and it makes a
great hiss as he does so, even thus did the Cyclops' eye hiss round the
beam of olive wood, and his hideous yells made the cave ring again. We

characters.name: Ulysses

characters.quote: 'Look here, Cyclops,' said I, you have been eating a great deal of man's flesh, s'take this and drink some wine, that you may see what kind of liquor we had on board my ship.

characters.name: Polyphemus
characters.role: Antagonist, capturing and eating Odysseus' men
characters.quote: 'Then I will eat all Noman's comrades before Noman himself, and will keep Noman for the last.'

scenes.title: The Escape from the Cave
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men escape from the Cyclops' cave disguised as sheep.
scenes.text:
ran away in a fright, but he plucked the beam all besmirched with gore
from his eye, and hurled it from him in a frenzy of rage and pain,
shouting as he did s't'the other Cyclopes wh'lived on the bleak
headlands near him; s'they gathered from all quarters round his cave
when they heard him crying, and asked what was the matter with him.
"'What ails you, Polyphemus,' said they, 'that you make such a noise,
breaking the stillness of the night, and preventing us from being able
t'sleep? Surely n'man is carrying off your sheep? Surely n'man is
trying t'kill you either by fraud or by force?'
"But Polyphemus shouted t'them from inside the cave, 'Noman is killing
me by fraud; n'man is killing me by force.'
"'Then,' said they, 'if n'man is attacking you, you must be ill; when
Jove makes people ill, there is n'help for it, and you had better pray
t'your father Neptune.'
"Then they went away, and I laughed inwardly at the success of my
clever stratagem, but the Cyclops, groaning and in an agony of pain,
felt about with his hands till he found the stone and took it from the
door; then he sat in the doorway and stretched his hands in front of it
t'catch anyone going out with the sheep, for he thought I might be
foolish enough t'attempt this.
"As for myself I kept on puzzling t'think how I could best save my own
life and those of my companions; I schemed and schemed, as one who
knows that his life depends upon it, for the danger was very great. In
the end I deemed that this plan would be the best; the male sheep were
well grown, and carried a heavy black fleece, s'I bound them
noiselessly in threes together, with some of the withies on which the
wicked monster used t'sleep. There was t'be a man under the middle
sheep, and the tw'on either side were t'cover him, s'that there were
three sheep t'each man. As for myself there was a ram finer than any
of the others, s'I caught hold of him by the back, esconced myself in
the thick wool under his belly, and hung on patiently t'his fleece,
face upwards, keeping a firm hold on it all the time.
"Thus, then, did we wait in great fear of mind till morning came, but
when the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, the male sheep
hurried out t'feed, while the ewes remained bleating about the pens
waiting t'be milked, for their udders were full t'bursting; but their
master in spite of all his pain felt the backs of all the sheep as they
stood upright, without being sharp enough t'find out that the men were
underneath their bellies. As the ram was going out, last of all, heavy
with its fleece and with the weight of my crafty self, Polyphemus laid
hold of it and said:
"'My good ram, what is it that makes you the last t'leave my cave this
morning? You are not wont t'let the ewes g'before you, but lead the
mob with a run whether t'flowery mead or bubbling fountain, and are
the first t'come home again at night; but now you lag last of all. Is
it because you know your master has lost his eye, and are sorry because
that wicked Noman and his horrid crew has got him down in his drink and
blinded him? But I will have his life yet. If you could understand and
talk, you would tell me where the wretch is hiding, and I would dash
his brains upon the ground till they flew all over the cave. I should
thus have some satisfaction for the harm this no-good Noman has done
me.'
"As he spoke he drove the ram outside, but when we were a little way
out from the cave and yards, I first got from under the ram's belly,
and then freed my comrades; as for the sheep, which were very fat, by
constantly heading them in the right direction we managed t'drive them
down t'the ship. The crew rejoiced greatly at seeing those of us who
had escaped death, but wept for the others whom the Cyclops had killed.

characters.name: Polyphemus
characters.role: A blinded Cyclops seeking revenge
characters.quote: 'Noman is killing me by fraud; n'man is killing me by force.'

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: The clever hero planning escape
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Odysseus is deeply focused on devising a plan to escape from Polyphemus, feeling the weight of the danger they are in.

scenes.title: Ulysses Taunts Polyphemus
scenes.summary: Ulysses taunts the Cyclops after escaping, leading to further trouble.
scenes.text:
However, I made signs t'them by nodding and frowning that they were to
hush their crying, and told them t'get all the sheep on board at once
and put out t'sea; s'they went aboard, took their places, and smote
the grey sea with their oars. Then, when I had got as far out as my
voice would reach, I began t'jeer at the Cyclops.
"'Cyclops,' said I, 'you should have taken better measure of your man
before eating up his comrades in your cave. You wretch, eat up your
visitors in your own house? You might have known that your sin would
find you out, and now Jove and the other gods have punished you.'
"He got more and more furious as he heard me, s'he tore the top from
off a high mountain, and flung it just in front of my ship s'that it
was within a little of hitting the end of the rudder.81 The sea quaked
as the rock fell int'it, and the wash of the wave it raised carried us
back towards the mainland, and forced us towards the shore. But I
snatched up a long pole and kept the ship off, making signs t'my men
by nodding my head, that they must row for their lives, whereon they
laid out with a will. When we had got twice as far as we were before, I
was for jeering at the Cyclops again, but the men begged and prayed of
me t'hold my tongue.
"'D'not,' they exclaimed, 'be mad enough t'provoke this savage
creature further; he has thrown one rock at us already which drove us
back again t'the mainland, and we made sure it had been the death of
us; if he had then heard any further sound of voices he would have
pounded our heads and our ship's timbers int'a jelly with the rugged
rocks he would have heaved at us, for he can throw them a long way.'
"But I would not listen t'them, and shouted out t'him in my rage,
'Cyclops, if any one asks you wh'it was that put your eye out and
spoiled your beauty, say it was the valiant warrior Ulysses, son of
Laertes, wh'lives in Ithaca.'

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Protagonist taunting the Cyclops
characters.quote: 'Cyclops,' said I, 'you should have taken better measure of your man before eating up his comrades in your cave.'

characters.name: Polyphemus
characters.role: Antagonist reacting to Ulysses' taunts
characters.quote: He got more and more furious as he heard me, s'he tore the top from off a high mountain, and flung it just in front of my ship s'that it was within a little of hitting the end of the rudder.

characters.name: Ulysses' Men
characters.role: Advisors warning Ulysses
characters.quote: 'D'not,' they exclaimed, 'be mad enough t'provoke this savage creature further; he has thrown one rock at us already which drove us back again t'the mainland.'

scenes.title: Neptune's Curse
scenes.summary: Polyphemus prays to Neptune for revenge against Ulysses.
scenes.text:
"On this he groaned, and cried out, 'Alas, alas, then the old prophecy
about me is coming true. There was a prophet here, at one time, a man
both brave and of great stature, Telemus son of Eurymus, wh'was an
excellent seer, and did all the prophesying for the Cyclopes till he
grew old; he told me that all this would happen t'me some day, and
said I should lose my sight by the hand of Ulysses. I have been all
along expecting some one of imposing presence and superhuman strength,
whereas he turns out t'be a little insignificant weakling, wh'has
managed t'blind my eye by taking advantage of me in my drink; come
here, then, Ulysses, that I may make you presents t'show my
hospitality, and urge Neptune t'help you forward on your journey—for
Neptune and I are father and son. He, if he s'will, shall heal me,
which n'one else neither god nor man can do.'
"Then I said, 'I wish I could be as sure of killing you outright and
sending you down t'the house of Hades, as I am that it will take more
than Neptune t'cure that eye of yours.'
"On this he lifted up his hands t'the firmament of heaven and prayed,
saying, 'Hear me, great Neptune; if I am indeed your own true begotten
son, grant that Ulysses may never reach his home alive; or if he must
get back t'his friends at last, let him d's'late and in sore plight
after losing all his men [let him reach his home in another man's ship
and find trouble in his house.'82
"Thus did he pray, and Neptune heard his prayer. Then he picked up a

characters.name: Polyphemus
characters.role: A blinded Cyclops seeking revenge on Ulysses
characters.quote: 'Alas, alas, then the old prophecy about me is coming true.'

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: The hero who blinds Polyphemus and taunts him
characters.quote: 'I wish I could be as sure of killing you outright and sending you down t'the house of Hades, as I am that it will take more than Neptune t'cure that eye of yours.'

scenes.title: Return to the Ships
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men return to their ships after the encounter with the Cyclops.
scenes.text:
rock much larger than the first, swung it aloft and hurled it with
prodigious force. It fell just short of the ship, but was within a
little of hitting the end of the rudder. The sea quaked as the rock
fell int'it, and the wash of the wave it raised drove us onwards on
our way towards the shore of the island.
"When at last we got t'the island where we had left the rest of our
ships, we found our comrades lamenting us, and anxiously awaiting our
return. We ran our vessel upon the sands and got out of her on t'the
sea shore; we als'landed the Cyclops' sheep, and divided them
equitably amongst us s'that none might have reason t'complain. As for
the ram, my companions agreed that I should have it as an extra share;
s'I sacrificed it on the sea shore, and burned its thigh bones to
Jove, wh'is the lord of all. But he heeded not my sacrifice, and only
thought how he might destroy both my ships and my comrades.
"Thus through the livelong day t'the going down of the sun we feasted
our fill on meat and drink, but when the sun went down and it came on
dark, we camped upon the beach. When the child of morning rosy-fingered
Dawn appeared, I bade my men on board and loose the hawsers. Then they
took their places and smote the grey sea with their oars; s'we sailed
on with sorrow in our hearts, but glad t'have escaped death though we
had lost our comrades.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Leader of the group, sacrifices a ram to Jove
characters.quote: I sacrificed it on the sea shore, and burned its thigh bones to Jove, wh'is the lord of all.

characters.name: Polyphemus

characters.quote: But he heeded not my sacrifice, and only thought how he might destroy both my ships and my comrades.
