characters.quote: My dear child, I am sure you must be Ulysses himself, only I did not know you till I had actually touched and handled you.

scenes.title: Penelope's Dream
scenes.summary: Penelope shares her dream with Ulysses.
scenes.text:
"Stranger, I should like t'speak with you briefly about another
matter. It is indeed nearly bed time—for those, at least, wh'can sleep
in spite of sorrow. As for myself, heaven has given me a life of such
unmeasurable woe, that even by day when I am attending t'my duties and
looking after the servants, I am still weeping and lamenting during the
whole time; then, when night comes, and we all of us g't'bed, I lie
awake thinking, and my heart becomes a prey t'the most incessant and
cruel tortures. As the dun nightingale, daughter of Pandareus, sings in
the early spring from her seat in shadiest covert hid, and with many a
plaintive trill pours out the tale how by mishap she killed her own
child Itylus, son of king Zethus, even s'does my mind toss and turn in
its uncertainty whether I ought t'stay with my son here, and safeguard
my substance, my bondsmen, and the greatness of my house, out of regard
t'public opinion and the memory of my late husband, or whether it is
not now time for me t'g'with the best of these suitors wh'are wooing
me and making me such magnificent presents. As long as my son was still
young, and unable t'understand, he would not hear of my leaving my
husband's house, but now that he is full grown he begs and prays me to
d'so, being incensed at the way in which the suitors are eating up his
property. Listen, then, t'a dream that I have had and interpret it for
me if you can. I have twenty geese about the house that eat mash out of
a trough,155 and of which I am exceedingly fond. I dreamed that a great
eagle came swooping down from a mountain, and dug his curved beak into
the neck of each of them till he had killed them all. Presently he
soared off int'the sky, and left them lying dead about the yard;
whereon I wept in my dream till all my maids gathered round me, so
piteously was I grieving because the eagle had killed my geese. Then he
came back again, and perching on a projecting rafter spoke t'me with
human voice, and told me t'leave off crying. 'Be of good courage,' he
said, 'daughter of Icarius; this is n'dream, but a vision of good omen
that shall surely come t'pass. The geese are the suitors, and I am no
longer an eagle, but your own husband, wh'am come back t'you, and who
will bring these suitors t'a disgraceful end.' On this I woke, and
when I looked out I saw my geese at the trough eating their mash as
usual."

characters.name: Penelope
characters.role: Struggling with her feelings about the suitors and her son
characters.quote: As for myself, heaven has given me a life of such unmeasurable woe, that even by day when I am attending t'my duties and looking after the servants, I am still weeping and lamenting during the whole time; then, when night comes, and we all of us g't'bed, I lie awake thinking, and my heart becomes a prey t'the most incessant and cruel tortures.

characters.name: The Eagle (in The Dream)
characters.role: Symbol of hope and change for Penelope
characters.quote: 'Be of good courage,' he said, 'daughter of Icarius; this is n'dream, but a vision of good omen that shall surely come t'pass.'

scenes.title: Ulysses' Assurance
scenes.summary: Ulysses assures Penelope of her husband's return.
scenes.text:
"This dream, Madam," replied Ulysses, "can admit but of one
interpretation, for had not Ulysses himself told you how it shall be
fulfilled? The death of the suitors is portended, and not one single
one of them will escape."
And Penelope answered, "Stranger, dreams are very curious and
unaccountable things, and they d'not by any means invariably come
true. There are tw'gates through which these unsubstantial fancies
proceed; the one is of horn, and the other ivory. Those that come
through the gate of ivory are fatuous, but those from the gate of horn
mean something t'those that see them. I d'not think, however, that my
own dream came through the gate of horn, though I and my son should be
most thankful if it proves t'have done so. Furthermore I say—and lay
my saying t'your heart—the coming dawn will usher in the ill-omened
day that is t'sever me from the house of Ulysses, for I am about to
hold a tournament of axes. My husband used t'set up twelve axes in the
court, one in front of the other, like the stays upon which a ship is
built; he would then g'back from them and shoot an arrow through the
whole twelve. I shall make the suitors try t'd'the same thing, and
whichever of them can string the bow most easily, and send his arrow
through all the twelve axes, him will I follow, and quit this house of
my lawful husband, s'goodly and s'abounding in wealth. But even so, I
doubt not that I shall remember it in my dreams."
Then Ulysses answered, "Madam, wife of Ulysses, you need not defer your
tournament, for Ulysses will return ere ever they can string the bow,
handle it how they will, and send their arrows through the iron."

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Prophesizes the death of the suitors
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Ulysses feels confident and reassures others about the fate of the suitors.

characters.name: Penelope
characters.role: Expresses doubt about dreams and plans a tournament
characters.quote: Stranger, dreams are very curious and unaccountable things, and they d'not by any means invariably come true.

scenes.title: Ulysses Cannot Sleep
scenes.summary: Ulysses struggles with his thoughts about the suitors.
scenes.text:
ULYSSES CANNOT SLEEP—PENELOPE'S PRAYER T'DIANA—THE TW'SIGNS FROM
HEAVEN—EUMAEUS AND PHILOETIUS ARRIVE—THE SUITORS DINE—CTESIPPUS THROWS
AN OX'S FOOT AT ULYSSES—THEOCLYMENUS FORETELLS DISASTER AND LEAVES THE
HOUSE.
Ulysses slept in the cloister upon an undressed bullock's hide, on the
top of which he threw several skins of the sheep the suitors had eaten,
and Eurynome156 threw a cloak over him after he had laid himself down.
There, then, Ulysses lay wakefully brooding upon the way in which he
should kill the suitors; and by and by, the women wh'had been in the
habit of misconducting themselves with them, left the house giggling
and laughing with one another. This made Ulysses very angry, and he
doubted whether t'get up and kill every single one of them then and
there, or t'let them sleep one more and last time with the suitors.
His heart growled within him, and as a bitch with puppies growls and
shows her teeth when she sees a stranger, s'did his heart growl with
anger at the evil deeds that were being done: but he beat his breast
and said, "Heart, be still, you had worse than this t'bear on the day
when the terrible Cyclops ate your brave companions; yet you bore it in
silence till your cunning got you safe out of the cave, though you made
sure of being killed."
Thus he chided with his heart, and checked it int'endurance, but he
tossed about as one wh'turns a paunch full of blood and fat in front
of a hot fire, doing it first on one side and then on the other, that
he may get it cooked as soon as possible, even s'did he turn himself
about from side t'side, thinking all the time how, single handed as he
was, he should contrive t'kill s'large a body of men as the wicked
suitors. But by and by Minerva came down from heaven in the likeness of
a woman, and hovered over his head saying, "My poor unhappy man, why do
you lie awake in this way? This is your house: your wife is safe inside
it, and s'is your son wh'is just such a young man as any father may
be proud of."
"Goddess," answered Ulysses, "all that you have said is true, but I am
in some doubt as t'how I shall be able t'kill these wicked suitors
single handed, seeing what a number of them there always are. And there
is this further difficulty, which is still more considerable. Supposing
that with Jove's and your assistance I succeed in killing them, I must
ask you t'consider where I am t'escape t'from their avengers when it
is all over."
"For shame," replied Minerva, "why, any one else would trust a worse
ally than myself, even though that ally were only a mortal and less
wise than I am. Am I not a goddess, and have I not protected you
throughout in all your troubles? I tell you plainly that even though
there were fifty bands of men surrounding us and eager t'kill us, you
should take all their sheep and cattle, and drive them away with you.
But g't'sleep; it is a very bad thing t'lie awake all night, and you
shall be out of your troubles before long."
As she spoke she shed sleep over his eyes, and then went back to
Olympus.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Struggling with anger and doubt about killing the suitors
characters.quote: Heart, be still, you had worse than this t'bear on the day when the terrible Cyclops ate your brave companions; yet you bore it in silence till your cunning got you safe out of the cave, though you made sure of being killed.

characters.name: Minerva
characters.role: Encouraging Ulysses and providing reassurance
characters.quote: For shame, replied Minerva, why, any one else would trust a worse ally than myself, even though that ally were only a mortal and less wise than I am.

scenes.title: Penelope's Prayer
scenes.summary: Penelope prays to Diana for relief from her sorrow.
scenes.text:
While Ulysses was thus yielding himself t'a very deep slumber that
eased the burden of his sorrows, his admirable wife awoke, and sitting
up in her bed began t'cry. When she had relieved herself by weeping
she prayed t'Diana saying, "Great Goddess Diana, daughter of Jove,
drive an arrow int'my heart and slay me; or let some whirlwind snatch
me up and bear me through paths of darkness till it drop me int'the
mouths of over-flowing Oceanus, as it did the daughters of Pandareus.
The daughters of Pandareus lost their father and mother, for the gods
killed them, s'they were left orphans. But Venus took care of them,
and fed them on cheese, honey, and sweet wine. Jun'taught them to
excel all women in beauty of form and understanding; Diana gave them an
imposing presence, and Minerva endowed them with every kind of
accomplishment; but one day when Venus had gone up t'Olympus t'see
Jove about getting them married (for well does he know both what shall
happen and what not happen t'every one) the storm winds came and
spirited them away t'become handmaids t'the dread Erinyes. Even s'I
wish that the gods wh'live in heaven would hide me from mortal sight,
or that fair Diana might strike me, for I would fain g'even beneath
the sad earth if I might d's'still looking towards Ulysses only, and
without having t'yield myself t'a worse man than he was. Besides, no
matter how much people may grieve by day, they can put up with it so
long as they can sleep at night, for when the eyes are closed in
slumber people forget good and ill alike; whereas my misery haunts me
even in my dreams. This very night methought there was one lying by my
side wh'was like Ulysses as he was when he went away with his host,
and I rejoiced, for I believed that it was n'dream, but the very truth
itself."
On this the day broke, but Ulysses heard the sound of her weeping, and
it puzzled him, for it seemed as though she already knew him and was by
his side. Then he gathered up the cloak and the fleeces on which he had
lain, and set them on a seat in the cloister, but he took the bullock's
hide out int'the open. He lifted up his hands t'heaven, and prayed,
saying "Father Jove, since you have seen fit t'bring me over land and
sea t'my own home after all the afflictions you have laid upon me,
give me a sign out of the mouth of some one or other of those wh'are
now waking within the house, and let me have another sign of some kind
from outside."
Thus did he pray. Jove heard his prayer and forthwith thundered high up
among the clouds from the splendour of Olympus, and Ulysses was glad
when he heard it. At the same time within the house, a miller-woman
from hard by in the mill room lifted up her voice and gave him another
sign. There were twelve miller-women whose business it was t'grind
wheat and barley which are the staff of life. The others had ground
their task and had gone t'take their rest, but this one had not yet
finished, for she was not s'strong as they were, and when she heard
the thunder she stopped grinding and gave the sign t'her master.
"Father Jove," said she, "you, wh'rule over heaven and earth, you have
thundered from a clear sky without s'much as a cloud in it, and this
means something for somebody; grant the prayer, then, of me your poor
servant wh'calls upon you, and let this be the very last day that the
suitors dine in the house of Ulysses. They have worn me out with labour
of grinding meal for them, and I hope they may never have another

scenes.summary: Ulysses receives omens from Jove and a miller-woman.
scenes.text:
dinner anywhere at all."
Ulysses was glad when he heard the omens conveyed t'him by the woman's
speech, and by the thunder, for he knew they meant that he should
avenge himself on the suitors.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Determined to avenge himself on the suitors
characters.quote: Ulysses was glad when he heard the omens conveyed t'him by the woman's speech, and by the thunder, for he knew they meant that he should avenge himself on the suitors.

scenes.title: Telemachus Prepares
scenes.summary: Telemachus gets ready to confront the suitors.
scenes.text:
Then the other maids in the house rose and lit the fire on the hearth;
Telemachus als'rose and put on his clothes. He girded his sword about
his shoulder, bound his sandals on t'his comely feet, and took a
doughty spear with a point of sharpened bronze; then he went t'the
threshold of the cloister and said t'Euryclea, "Nurse, did you make
the stranger comfortable both as regards bed and board, or did you let
him shift for himself?—for my mother, good woman though she is, has a
way of paying great attention t'second-rate people, and of neglecting
others wh'are in reality much better men."
"D'not find fault child," said Euryclea, "when there is n'one t'find
fault with. The stranger sat and drank his wine as long as he liked:
your mother did ask him if he would take any more bread and he said he
would not. When he wanted t'g't'bed she told the servants t'make
one for him, but he said he was such a wretched outcast that he would
not sleep on a bed and under blankets; he insisted on having an
undressed bullock's hide and some sheepskins put for him in the
cloister and I threw a cloak over him myself."157
Then Telemachus went out of the court t'the place where the Achaeans
were meeting in assembly; he had his spear in his hand, and he was not
alone, for his tw'dogs went with him. But Euryclea called the maids
and said, "Come, wake up; set about sweeping the cloisters and
sprinkling them with water t'lay the dust; put the covers on the
seats; wipe down the tables, some of you, with a wet sponge; clean out
the mixing-jugs and the cups, and g'for water from the fountain at
once; the suitors will be here directly; they will be here early, for
it is a feast day."

characters.name: Telemachus
characters.role: Concerned about the treatment of the stranger
characters.quote: "Nurse, did you make the stranger comfortable both as regards bed and board, or did you let him shift for himself?"

characters.name: Euryclea
characters.role: Defensive and informative about the stranger's treatment
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Euryclea is defensive and caring, urging Telemachus not to criticize without cause.

scenes.title: The Swineherd and Goatherd
scenes.summary: Eumaeus and Philoetius discuss Ulysses' fate.
scenes.text:
Thus did she speak, and they did even as she had said: twenty of them
went t'the fountain for water, and the others set themselves busily to
work about the house. The men wh'were in attendance on the suitors
als'came up and began chopping firewood. By and by the women returned
from the fountain, and the swineherd came after them with the three
best pigs he could pick out. These he let feed about the premises, and
then he said good-humouredly t'Ulysses, "Stranger, are the suitors
treating you any better now, or are they as insolent as ever?"
"May heaven," answered Ulysses, "requite t'them the wickedness with
which they deal high-handedly in another man's house without any sense
of shame."
Thus did they converse; meanwhile Melanthius the goatherd came up, for
he to'was bringing in his best goats for the suitors' dinner; and he
had tw'shepherds with him. They tied the goats up under the gatehouse,
and then Melanthius began gibing at Ulysses. "Are you still here,
stranger," said he, "t'pester people by begging about the house? Why
can you not g'elsewhere? You and I shall not come t'an understanding
before we have given each other a taste of our fists. You beg without
any sense of decency: are there not feasts elsewhere among the
Achaeans, as well as here?"
Ulysses made n'answer, but bowed his head and brooded. Then a third
man, Philoetius, joined them, wh'was bringing in a barren heifer and
some goats. These were brought over by the boatmen wh'are there to
take people over when any one comes t'them. S'Philoetius made his
heifer and his goats secure under the gatehouse, and then went up to
the swineherd. "Who, Swineherd," said he, "is this stranger that is
lately come here? Is he one of your men? What is his family? Where does
he come from? Poor fellow, he looks as if he had been some great man,
but the gods give sorrow t'whom they will—even t'kings if it so
pleases them."
As he spoke he went up t'Ulysses and saluted him with his right hand;
"Good day t'you, father stranger," said he, "you seem t'be very
poorly off now, but I hope you will have better times by and by. Father
Jove, of all gods you are the most malicious. We are your own children,
yet you show us n'mercy in all our misery and afflictions. A sweat
came over me when I saw this man, and my eyes filled with tears, for he
reminds me of Ulysses, wh'I fear is going about in just such rags as
this man's are, if indeed he is still among the living. If he is
already dead and in the house of Hades, then, alas! for my good master,
wh'made me his stockman when I was quite young among the
Cephallenians, and now his cattle are countless; n'one could have done
better with them than I have, for they have bred like ears of corn;
nevertheless I have t'keep bringing them in for others t'eat, who
take n'heed t'his son though he is in the house, and fear not the
wrath of heaven, but are already eager t'divide Ulysses' property
among them because he has been away s'long. I have often thought—only
it would not be right while his son is living—of going off with the
cattle t'some foreign country; bad as this would be, it is still
harder t'stay here and be ill-treated about other people's herds. My
position is intolerable, and I should long since have run away and put
myself under the protection of some other chief, only that I believe my
poor master will yet return, and send all these suitors flying out of

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: A disguised beggar seeking justice
characters.quote: "May heaven," answered Ulysses, "requite t'them the wickedness with which they deal high-handedly in another man's house without any sense of shame."

characters.name: Melanthius
characters.role: Antagonistic goatherd mocking Ulysses
characters.quote: "Are you still here, stranger," said he, "t'pester people by begging about the house?"

characters.name: Philoetius
characters.role: Loyal stockman expressing sorrow for Ulysses
characters.quote: "Good day t'you, father stranger," said he, "you seem t'be very poorly off now, but I hope you will have better times by and by."

scenes.title: The Suitors' Dinner
scenes.summary: The suitors dine and plot against Telemachus.
scenes.text:
the house."
"Stockman," answered Ulysses, "you seem t'be a very well-disposed
person, and I can see that you are a man of sense. Therefore I will
tell you, and will confirm my words with an oath. By Jove, the chief of
all gods, and by that hearth of Ulysses t'which I am now come, Ulysses
shall return before you leave this place, and if you are s'minded you
shall see him killing the suitors wh'are now masters here."
"If Jove were t'bring this t'pass," replied the stockman, "you should
see how I would d'my very utmost t'help him."
And in like manner Eumaeus prayed that Ulysses might return home.
Thus did they converse. Meanwhile the suitors were hatching a plot to
murder Telemachus: but a bird flew near them on their left hand—an
eagle with a dove in its talons. On this Amphinomus said, "My friends,
this plot of ours t'murder Telemachus will not succeed; let us g'to
dinner instead."
The others assented, s'they went inside and laid their cloaks on the
benches and seats. They sacrificed the sheep, goats, pigs, and the
heifer, and when the inward meats were cooked they served them round.
They mixed the wine in the mixing-bowls, and the swineherd gave every
man his cup, while Philoetius handed round the bread in the bread
baskets, and Melanthius poured them out their wine. Then they laid
their hands upon the good things that were before them.
Telemachus purposely made Ulysses sit in the part of the cloister that
was paved with stone;158 he gave him a shabby looking seat at a little
table t'himself, and had his portion of the inward meats brought to
him, with his wine in a gold cup. "Sit there," said he, "and drink your
wine among the great people. I will put a stop t'the gibes and blows
of the suitors, for this is n'public house, but belongs t'Ulysses,
and has passed from him t'me. Therefore, suitors, keep your hands and
your tongues t'yourselves, or there will be mischief."
The suitors bit their lips, and marvelled at the boldness of his
speech; then Antinous said, "We d'not like such language but we will
put up with it, for Telemachus is threatening us in good earnest. If
Jove had let us we should have put a stop t'his brave talk ere now."
Thus spoke Antinous, but Telemachus heeded him not. Meanwhile the
heralds were bringing the holy hecatomb through the city, and the
Achaeans gathered under the shady grove of Apollo.
Then they roasted the outer meat, drew it off the spits, gave every man
his portion, and feasted t'their heart's content; those wh'waited at
table gave Ulysses exactly the same portion as the others had, for
Telemachus had told them t'd'so.
But Minerva would not let the suitors for one moment drop their
insolence, for she wanted Ulysses t'become still more bitter against
them. Now there happened t'be among them a ribald fellow, whose name
was Ctesippus, and wh'came from Same. This man, confident in his great
wealth, was paying court t'the wife of Ulysses, and said t'the
suitors, "Hear what I have t'say. The stranger has already had as
large a portion as any one else; this is well, for it is not right nor
reasonable t'ill-treat any guest of Telemachus wh'comes here. I will,
however, make him a present on my own account, that he may have
something t'give t'the bath-woman, or t'some other of Ulysses'
servants."
As he spoke he picked up a heifer's foot from the meat-basket in which
it lay, and threw it at Ulysses, but Ulysses turned his head a little
aside, and avoided it, smiling grimly Sardinian fashion159 as he did
so, and it hit the wall, not him. On this Telemachus spoke fiercely to
Ctesippus, "It is a good thing for you," said he, "that the stranger
turned his head s'that you missed him. If you had hit him I should
have run you through with my spear, and your father would have had to
see about getting you buried rather than married in this house. S'let
me have n'more unseemly behaviour from any of you, for I am grown up
now t'the knowledge of good and evil and understand what is going on,
instead of being the child that I have been heretofore. I have long
seen you killing my sheep and making free with my corn and wine: I have
put up with this, for one man is n'match for many, but d'me no
further violence. Still, if you wish t'kill me, kill me; I would far
rather die than see such disgraceful scenes day after day—guests
insulted, and men dragging the women servants about the house in an
unseemly way."
They all held their peace till at last Agelaus son of Damastor said,
"N'one should take offence at what has just been said, nor gainsay it,
for it is quite reasonable. Leave off, therefore, ill-treating the
stranger, or any one else of the servants wh'are about the house; I
would say, however, a friendly word t'Telemachus and his mother, which
I trust may commend itself t'both. 'As long,' I would say, 'as you had
ground for hoping that Ulysses would one day come home, n'one could
complain of your waiting and suffering160 the suitors t'be in your
house. It would have been better that he should have returned, but it
is now sufficiently clear that he will never d'so; therefore talk all
this quietly over with your mother, and tell her t'marry the best man,
and the one wh'makes her the most advantageous offer. Thus you will
yourself be able t'manage your own inheritance, and t'eat and drink
in peace, while your mother will look after some other man's house, not
yours.'"
T'this Telemachus answered, "By Jove, Agelaus, and by the sorrows of
my unhappy father, wh'has either perished far from Ithaca, or is
wandering in some distant land, I throw n'obstacles in the way of my
mother's marriage; on the contrary I urge her t'choose whomsoever she
will, and I will give her numberless gifts int'the bargain, but I dare
not insist point blank that she shall leave the house against her own
wishes. Heaven forbid that I should d'this."
Minerva now made the suitors fall t'laughing immoderately, and set
their wits wandering; but they were laughing with a forced laughter.
Their meat became smeared with blood; their eyes filled with tears, and
their hearts were heavy with forebodings. Theoclymenus saw this and
said, "Unhappy men, what is it that ails you? There is a shroud of
darkness drawn over you from head t'foot, your cheeks are wet with
tears; the air is alive with wailing voices; the walls and roof-beams
drip blood; the gate of the cloisters and the court beyond them are
full of ghosts trooping down int'the night of hell; the sun is blotted
out of heaven, and a blighting gloom is over all the land."
Thus did he speak, and they all of them laughed heartily. Eurymachus
then said, "This stranger wh'has lately come here has lost his senses.
Servants, turn him out int'the streets, since he finds it s'dark
here."
But Theoclymenus said, "Eurymachus, you need not send any one with me.
I have eyes, ears, and a pair of feet of my own, t'say nothing of an
understanding mind. I will take these out of the house with me, for I
see mischief overhanging you, from which not one of you men wh'are
insulting people and plotting ill deeds in the house of Ulysses will be
able t'escape."
He left the house as he spoke, and went back t'Piraeus wh'gave him
welcome, but the suitors kept looking at one another and provoking
Telemachus by laughing at the strangers. One insolent fellow said to
him, "Telemachus, you are not happy in your guests; first you have this
importunate tramp, wh'comes begging bread and wine and has n'skill
for work or for hard fighting, but is perfectly useless, and now here
is another fellow wh'is setting himself up as a prophet. Let me
persuade you, for it will be much better t'put them on board ship and
send them off t'the Sicels t'sell for what they will bring."
Telemachus gave him n'heed, but sat silently watching his father,
expecting every moment that he would begin his attack upon the suitors.
Meanwhile the daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope, had had a rich seat
placed for her facing the court and cloisters, s'that she could hear
what every one was saying. The dinner indeed had been prepared amid
much merriment; it had been both good and abundant, for they had
sacrificed many victims; but the supper was yet t'come, and nothing
can be conceived more gruesome than the meal which a goddess and a
brave man were soon t'lay before them—for they had brought their doom
upon themselves.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: The disguised father of Telemachus, plotting revenge against the suitors.
characters.quote: Ulysses shall return before you leave this place, and if you are s'minded you shall see him killing the suitors wh'are now masters here.

characters.name: Telemachus
characters.role: The son of Ulysses, asserting his authority against the suitors.
characters.quote: I will put a stop t'the gibes and blows of the suitors, for this is n'public house, but belongs t'Ulysses, and has passed from him t'me.

characters.name: Antinous
characters.role: A leading suitor, representing the opposition to Telemachus.
characters.quote: We d'not like such language but we will put up with it, for Telemachus is threatening us in good earnest.

characters.name: Ctesippus
characters.role: A suitor who insults Ulysses, showing the suitors' arrogance.
characters.quote: I will, however, make him a present on my own account, that he may have something t'give t'the bath-woman, or t'some other of Ulysses' servants.

characters.name: Theoclymenus
characters.role: A prophet who warns the suitors of their impending doom.
characters.quote: I see mischief overhanging you, from which not one of you men wh'are insulting people and plotting ill deeds in the house of Ulysses will be able t'escape.

scenes.title: Penelope's Plan
scenes.summary: Penelope decides to challenge the suitors with Ulysses' bow.
scenes.text:
THE TRIAL OF THE AXES, DURING WHICH ULYSSES REVEALS HIMSELF T'EUMAEUS
AND PHILOETIUS
Minerva now put it in Penelope's mind t'make the suitors try their
skill with the bow and with the iron axes, in contest among themselves,
as a means of bringing about their destruction. She went upstairs and
got the store-room key, which was made of bronze and had a handle of
ivory; she then went with her maidens int'the store-room at the end of
the house, where her husband's treasures of gold, bronze, and wrought
iron were kept, and where was als'his bow, and the quiver full of
deadly arrows that had been given him by a friend whom he had met in
Lacedaemon—Iphitus the son of Eurytus. The tw'fell in with one another
in Messene at the house of Ortilochus, where Ulysses was staying in
order t'recover a debt that was owing from the whole people; for the
Messenians had carried off three hundred sheep from Ithaca, and had
sailed away with them and with their shepherds. In quest of these
Ulysses took a long journey while still quite young, for his father and
the other chieftains sent him on a mission t'recover them. Iphitus had
gone there als't'try and get back twelve brood mares that he had
lost, and the mule foals that were running with them. These mares were
the death of him in the end, for when he went t'the house of Jove's
son, mighty Hercules, wh'performed such prodigies of valour, Hercules
t'his shame killed him, though he was his guest, for he feared not
heaven's vengeance, nor yet respected his own table which he had set
before Iphitus, but killed him in spite of everything, and kept the
mares himself. It was when claiming these that Iphitus met Ulysses, and
gave him the bow which mighty Eurytus had been used t'carry, and which
on his death had been left by him t'his son. Ulysses gave him in
return a sword and a spear, and this was the beginning of a fast
friendship, although they never visited at one another's houses, for
Jove's son Hercules killed Iphitus ere they could d'so. This bow,
then, given him by Iphitus, had not been taken with him by Ulysses when
he sailed for Troy; he had used it s'long as he had been at home, but
had left it behind as having been a keepsake from a valued friend.
Penelope presently reached the oak threshold of the store-room; the
carpenter had planed this duly, and had drawn a line on it s'as t'get
it quite straight; he had then set the door posts int'it and hung the
doors. She loosed the strap from the handle of the door, put in the
key, and drove it straight home t'shoot back the bolts that held the
doors;161 these flew open with a noise like a bull bellowing in a
meadow, and Penelope stepped upon the raised platform, where the chests
stood in which the fair linen and clothes were laid by along with
fragrant herbs: reaching thence, she took down the bow with its bow
case from the peg on which it hung. She sat down with it on her knees,
weeping bitterly as she took the bow out of its case, and when her
tears had relieved her, she went t'the cloister where the suitors
were, carrying the bow and the quiver, with the many deadly arrows that
were inside it. Along with her came her maidens, bearing a chest that
contained much iron and bronze which her husband had won as prizes.
When she reached the suitors, she stood by one of the bearing-posts
supporting the roof of the cloister, holding a veil before her face,
and with a maid on either side of her. Then she said:
"Listen t'me you suitors, wh'persist in abusing the hospitality of
this house because its owner has been long absent, and without other
pretext than that you want t'marry me; this, then, being the prize
that you are contending for, I will bring out the mighty bow of
Ulysses, and whomsoever of you shall string it most easily and send his
arrow through each one of twelve axes, him will I follow and quit this
house of my lawful husband, s'goodly, and s'abounding in wealth. But
even s'I doubt not that I shall remember it in my dreams."
As she spoke, she told Eumaeus t'set the bow and the pieces of iron
before the suitors, and Eumaeus wept as he took them t'd'as she had

characters.name: Penelope
characters.role: Proposing the contest with the bow
characters.quote: "Listen t'me you suitors, wh'persist in abusing the hospitality of this house because its owner has been long absent, and without other pretext than that you want t'marry me; this, then, being the prize that you are contending for, I will bring out the mighty bow of Ulysses, and whomsoever of you shall string it most easily and send his arrow through each one of twelve axes, him will I follow and quit this house of my lawful husband, s'goodly, and s'abounding in wealth. But even s'I doubt not that I shall remember it in my dreams."

characters.name: Eumaeus
characters.role: Assisting Penelope and feeling sorrowful
characters.quote: No quote available

scenes.title: The Contest Begins
scenes.summary: The suitors prepare to compete for Penelope's hand.
scenes.text:
bidden him. Hard by, the stockman wept als'when he saw his master's
bow, but Antinous scolded them. "You country louts," said he, "silly
simpletons; why should you add t'the sorrows of your mistress by
crying in this way? She has enough t'grieve her in the loss of her
husband; sit still, therefore, and eat your dinners in silence, or go
outside if you want t'cry, and leave the bow behind you. We suitors
shall have t'contend for it with might and main, for we shall find it
n'light matter t'string such a bow as this is. There is not a man of
us all wh'is such another as Ulysses; for I have seen him and remember
him, though I was then only a child."
This was what he said, but all the time he was expecting t'be able to
string the bow and shoot through the iron, whereas in fact he was t'be
the first that should taste of the arrows from the hands of Ulysses,
whom he was dishonouring in his own house—egging the others on t'd'so
also.
Then Telemachus spoke. "Great heavens!" he exclaimed, "Jove must have
robbed me of my senses. Here is my dear and excellent mother saying she
will quit this house and marry again, yet I am laughing and enjoying
myself as though there were nothing happening. But, suitors, as the
contest has been agreed upon, let it g'forward. It is for a woman
whose peer is not t'be found in Pylos, Argos, or Mycene, nor yet in
Ithaca nor on the mainland. You know this as well as I do; what need
have I t'speak in praise of my mother? Come on, then, make n'excuses
for delay, but let us see whether you can string the bow or no. I too
will make trial of it, for if I can string it and shoot through the
iron, I shall not suffer my mother t'quit this house with a stranger,
not if I can win the prizes which my father won before me."
As he spoke he sprang from his seat, threw his crimson cloak from him,
and took his sword from his shoulder. First he set the axes in a row,
in a long groove which he had dug for them, and had made straight by
line.162 Then he stamped the earth tight round them, and everyone was
surprised when they saw him set them up s'orderly, though he had never
seen anything of the kind before. This done, he went on t'the pavement
t'make trial of the bow; thrice did he tug at it, trying with all his
might t'draw the string, and thrice he had t'leave off, though he had
hoped t'string the bow and shoot through the iron. He was trying for
the fourth time, and would have strung it had not Ulysses made a sign
t'check him in spite of all his eagerness. S'he said:
"Alas! I shall either be always feeble and of n'prowess, or I am too
young, and have not yet reached my full strength s'as t'be able to
hold my own if any one attacks me. You others, therefore, wh'are
stronger than I, make trial of the bow and get this contest settled."
On this he put the bow down, letting it lean against the door [that led
int'the house] with the arrow standing against the top of the bow.
Then he sat down on the seat from which he had risen, and Antinous
said:
"Come on each of you in his turn, going towards the right from the

characters.name: Antinous
characters.role: Leader of the suitors, mocking Telemachus
characters.quote: "You country louts," said he, "silly simpletons; why should you add t'the sorrows of your mistress by crying in this way?"

characters.name: Telemachus
characters.role: Defending his mother and challenging the suitors
characters.quote: "Great heavens!" he exclaimed, "Jove must have robbed me of my senses. Here is my dear and excellent mother saying she will quit this house and marry again, yet I am laughing and enjoying myself as though there were nothing happening."

scenes.title: Ulysses Reveals Himself
scenes.summary: Ulysses speaks to Eumaeus and Philoetius, revealing his identity.
scenes.text:
Then the swineherd and the stockman left the cloisters together, and
Ulysses followed them. When they had got outside the gates and the
outer yard, Ulysses said t'them quietly:
"Stockman, and you swineherd, I have something in my mind which I am in
doubt whether t'say or no; but I think I will say it. What manner of
men would you be t'stand by Ulysses, if some god should bring him back
here all of a sudden? Say which you are disposed t'do—t'side with the
suitors, or with Ulysses?"
"Father Jove," answered the stockman, "would indeed that you might so
ordain it. If some god were but t'bring Ulysses back, you should see
with what might and main I would fight for him."
In like words Eumaeus prayed t'all the gods that Ulysses might return;
when, therefore, he saw for certain what mind they were of, Ulysses
said, "It is I, Ulysses, wh'am here. I have suffered much, but at
last, in the twentieth year, I am come back t'my own country. I find
that you tw'alone of all my servants are glad that I should d'so, for
I have not heard any of the others praying for my return. T'you two,
therefore, will I unfold the truth as it shall be. If heaven shall
deliver the suitors int'my hands, I will find wives for both of you,
will give you house and holding close t'my own, and you shall be t'me
as though you were brothers and friends of Telemachus. I will now give
you convincing proofs that you may know me and be assured. See, here is
the scar from the boar's tooth that ripped me when I was out hunting on
Mt. Parnassus with the sons of Autolycus."
As he spoke he drew his rags aside from the great scar, and when they
had examined it thoroughly, they both of them wept about Ulysses, threw
their arms round him, and kissed his head and shoulders, while Ulysses
kissed their hands and faces in return. The sun would have gone down
upon their mourning if Ulysses had not checked them and said:
"Cease your weeping, lest some one should come outside and see us, and
tell those wh'are within. When you g'in, d's'separately, not both
together; I will g'first, and d'you follow afterwards; let this
moreover be the token between us; the suitors will all of them try to
prevent me from getting hold of the bow and quiver; d'you, therefore,
Eumaeus, place it in my hands when you are carrying it about, and tell
the women t'close the doors of their apartment. If they hear any
groaning or uproar as of men fighting about the house, they must not
come out; they must keep quiet, and stay where they are at their work.
And I charge you, Philoetius, t'make fast the doors of the outer
court, and t'bind them securely at once."

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Reveals his identity and plans
characters.quote: It is I, Ulysses, wh'am here. I have suffered much, but at last, in the twentieth year, I am come back t'my own country.

characters.name: Stockman
characters.role: Expresses loyalty and desire to fight for Ulysses
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Stockman shows loyalty and eagerness to fight for Ulysses' return.

characters.name: Eumaeus
characters.role: Shows loyalty and emotional support for Ulysses
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Eumaeus expresses deep emotion and loyalty towards Ulysses, weeping and embracing him.

characters.name: Philoetius
characters.role: Follows Ulysses' orders to secure the area
characters.quote: No quote available

scenes.title: The Bow is Presented
scenes.summary: Telemachus insists the bow be given to the stranger.
scenes.text:
When he had thus spoken, he went back t'the house and took the seat
that he had left. Presently, his tw'servants followed him inside.
At this moment the bow was in the hands of Eurymachus, wh'was warming
it by the fire, but even s'he could not string it, and he was greatly
grieved. He heaved a deep sigh and said, "I grieve for myself and for
us all; I grieve that I shall have t'forg'the marriage, but I d'not
care nearly s'much about this, for there are plenty of other women in
Ithaca and elsewhere; what I feel most is the fact of our being so
inferior t'Ulysses in strength that we cannot string his bow. This
will disgrace us in the eyes of those wh'are yet unborn."
"It shall not be so, Eurymachus," said Antinous, "and you know it
yourself. Today is the feast of Apoll'throughout all the land; wh'can
string a bow on such a day as this? Put it on one side—as for the axes
they can stay where they are, for n'one is likely t'come t'the house
and take them away: let the cupbearer g'round with his cups, that we
may make our drink-offerings and drop this matter of the bow; we will
tell Melanthius t'bring us in some goats tomorrow—the best he has; we
can then offer thigh bones t'Apoll'the mighty archer, and again make
trial of the bow, s'as t'bring the contest t'an end."
The rest approved his words, and thereon men servants poured water over
the hands of the guests, while pages filled the mixing-bowls with wine
and water and handed it round after giving every man his
drink-offering. Then, when they had made their offerings and had drunk
each as much as he desired, Ulysses craftily said:—
"Suitors of the illustrious queen, listen that I may speak even as I am
minded. I appeal more especially t'Eurymachus, and t'Antinous wh'has
just spoken with s'much reason. Cease shooting for the present and
leave the matter t'the gods, but in the morning let heaven give
victory t'whom it will. For the moment, however, give me the bow that
I may prove the power of my hands among you all, and see whether I
still have as much strength as I used t'have, or whether travel and
neglect have made an end of it."
This made them all very angry, for they feared he might string the bow,
Antinous therefore rebuked him fiercely saying, "Wretched creature, you
have not s'much as a grain of sense in your whole body; you ought to
think yourself lucky in being allowed t'dine unharmed among your
betters, without having any smaller portion served you than we others
have had, and in being allowed t'hear our conversation. N'other
beggar or stranger has been allowed t'hear what we say among
ourselves; the wine must have been doing you a mischief, as it does
with all those wh'drink immoderately. It was wine that inflamed the
Centaur Eurytion when he was staying with Peirithous among the
Lapithae. When the wine had got int'his head, he went mad and did ill
deeds about the house of Peirithous; this angered the heroes wh'were
there assembled, s'they rushed at him and cut off his ears and
nostrils; then they dragged him through the doorway out of the house,
s'he went away crazed, and bore the burden of his crime, bereft of
understanding. Henceforth, therefore, there was war between mankind and
the centaurs, but he brought it upon himself through his own
drunkenness. In like manner I can tell you that it will g'hardly with
you if you string the bow: you will find n'mercy from any one here,
for we shall at once ship you off t'king Echetus, wh'kills every one
that comes near him: you will never get away alive, s'drink and keep
quiet without getting int'a quarrel with men younger than yourself."
Penelope then spoke t'him. "Antinous," said she, "it is not right that
you should ill-treat any guest of Telemachus wh'comes t'this house.
If the stranger should prove strong enough t'string the mighty bow of
Ulysses, can you suppose that he would take me home with him and make
me his wife? Even the man himself can have n'such idea in his mind:
none of you need let that disturb his feasting; it would be out of all
reason."
"Queen Penelope," answered Eurymachus, "we d'not suppose that this man
will take you away with him; it is impossible; but we are afraid lest
some of the baser sort, men or women among the Achaeans, should go
gossiping about and say, 'These suitors are a feeble folk; they are
paying court t'the wife of a brave man whose bow not one of them was
able t'string, and yet a beggarly tramp wh'came t'the house strung
it at once and sent an arrow through the iron.' This is what will be
said, and it will be a scandal against us."
"Eurymachus," Penelope answered, "people wh'persist in eating up the
estate of a great chieftain and dishonouring his house must not expect
others t'think well of them. Why then should you mind if men talk as
you think they will? This stranger is strong and well-built, he says
moreover that he is of noble birth. Give him the bow, and let us see
whether he can string it or no. I say—and it shall surely be—that if
Apoll'vouchsafes him the glory of stringing it, I will give him a
cloak and shirt of good wear, with a javelin t'keep off dogs and
robbers, and a sharp sword. I will als'give him sandals, and will see
him sent safely wherever he wants t'go."
Then Telemachus said, "Mother, I am the only man either in Ithaca or in
the islands that are over against Elis wh'has the right t'let any one
have the bow or t'refuse it. N'one shall force me one way or the
other, not even though I choose t'make the stranger a present of the
bow outright, and let him take it away with him. Go, then, within the
house and busy yourself with your daily duties, your loom, your
distaff, and the ordering of your servants. This bow is a man's matter,
and mine above all others, for it is I wh'am master here."
She went wondering back int'the house, and laid her son's saying in
her heart. Then going upstairs with her handmaids int'her room, she
mourned her dear husband till Minerva sent sweet sleep over her
eyelids.
The swineherd now took up the bow and was for taking it t'Ulysses, but
the suitors clamoured at him from all parts of the cloisters, and one
of them said, "You idiot, where are you taking the bow to? Are you out
of your wits? If Apoll'and the other gods will grant our prayer, your
own boarhounds shall get you int'some quiet little place, and worry
you t'death."
Eumaeus was frightened at the outcry they all raised, s'he put the bow
down then and there, but Telemachus shouted out at him from the other
side of the cloisters, and threatened him saying, "Father Eumaeus,
bring the bow on in spite of them, or young as I am I will pelt you
with stones back t'the country, for I am the better man of the two. I
wish I was as much stronger than all the other suitors in the house as
I am than you, I would soon send some of them off sick and sorry, for
they mean mischief."
Thus did he speak, and they all of them laughed heartily, which put
them in a better humour with Telemachus; s'Eumaeus brought the bow on
and placed it in the hands of Ulysses. When he had done this, he called
Euryclea apart and said t'her, "Euryclea, Telemachus says you are to
close the doors of the women's apartments. If they hear any groaning or
uproar as of men fighting about the house, they are not t'come out,
but are t'keep quiet and stay where they are at their work."
Euryclea did as she was told and closed the doors of the women's
apartments.

characters.name: Eurymachus
characters.role: Expresses grief over inability to string the bow
characters.quote: I grieve for myself and for us all; I grieve that I shall have t'forg'the marriage, but I d'not care nearly s'much about this, for there are plenty of other women in Ithaca and elsewhere; what I feel most is the fact of our being so inferior t'Ulysses in strength that we cannot string his bow. This will disgrace us in the eyes of those wh'are yet unborn.

characters.name: Antinous
characters.role: Rebukes Ulysses and asserts superiority
characters.quote: Wretched creature, you have not s'much as a grain of sense in your whole body; you ought to think yourself lucky in being allowed t'dine unharmed among your betters, without having any smaller portion served you than we others have had, and in being allowed t'hear our conversation.

characters.name: Penelope
characters.role: Defends Ulysses and challenges the suitors
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Penelope feels defiant and concerned about the treatment of guests in her home.

characters.name: Telemachus
characters.role: Claims authority over the bow and defends Ulysses
characters.quote: Mother, I am the only man either in Ithaca or in the islands that are over against Elis wh'has the right t'let any one have the bow or t'refuse it.

characters.name: Eumaeus
characters.role: Attempts to bring the bow to Ulysses
characters.quote: You idiot, where are you taking the bow to? Are you out of your wits?
characters.fake_quote: Eumaeus hesitated and felt frightened by the suitors' outcry.

characters.name: Euryclea
characters.role: Follows Telemachus' orders to secure the women
characters.quote: Euryclea did as she was told and closed the doors of the women's apartments.

scenes.title: Ulysses Strings the Bow
scenes.summary: Ulysses successfully strings the bow, shocking the suitors.
scenes.text:
Meanwhile Philoetius slipped quietly out and made fast the gates of the
outer court. There was a ship's cable of byblus fibre lying in the
gatehouse, s'he made the gates fast with it and then came in again,
resuming the seat that he had left, and keeping an eye on Ulysses, who
had now got the bow in his hands, and was turning it every way about,
and proving it all over t'see whether the worms had been eating into
its tw'horns during his absence. Then would one turn towards his
neighbour saying, "This is some tricky old bow-fancier; either he has
got one like it at home, or he wants t'make one, in such workmanlike
style does the old vagabond handle it."
Another said, "I hope he may be n'more successful in other things than
he is likely t'be in stringing this bow."
But Ulysses, when he had taken it up and examined it all over, strung
it as easily as a skilled bard strings a new peg of his lyre and makes
the twisted gut fast at both ends. Then he took it in his right hand to
prove the string, and it sang sweetly under his touch like the
twittering of a swallow. The suitors were dismayed, and turned colour
as they heard it; at that moment, moreover, Jove thundered loudly as a
sign, and the heart of Ulysses rejoiced as he heard the omen that the
son of scheming Saturn had sent him.
He took an arrow that was lying upon the table165—for those which the
Achaeans were s'shortly about t'taste were all inside the quiver—he
laid it on the centre-piece of the bow, and drew the notch of the arrow
and the string toward him, still seated on his seat. When he had taken
aim he let fly, and his arrow pierced every one of the handle-holes of
the axes from the first onwards till it had gone right through them,
and int'the outer courtyard. Then he said t'Telemachus:
"Your guest has not disgraced you, Telemachus. I did not miss what I
aimed at, and I was not long in stringing my bow. I am still strong,
and not as the suitors twit me with being. Now, however, it is time for
the Achaeans t'prepare supper while there is still daylight, and then
otherwise t'disport themselves with song and dance which are the
crowning ornaments of a banquet."

characters.name: Philoetius
characters.role: Secures the gates to prevent escape
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Philoetius is focused on his task of securing the gates, showing his loyalty and diligence.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Proves his strength and skill with the bow
characters.quote: Your guest has not disgraced you, Telemachus. I did not miss what I aimed at, and I was not long in stringing my bow.

characters.name: Telemachus
characters.role: Witnesses Ulysses' skill and strength
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Telemachus feels a sense of pride and hope as he watches Ulysses demonstrate his strength.

characters.name: Suitors
characters.role: Doubt Ulysses' abilities and are dismayed by his success
characters.quote: This is some tricky old bow-fancier; either he has got one like it at home, or he wants t'make one, in such workmanlike style does the old vagabond handle it.

scenes.title: Ulysses Reveals Himself 2
scenes.summary: Ulysses reveals his identity and kills Antinous.
scenes.text:
Then Ulysses tore off his rags, and sprang on t'the broad pavement
with his bow and his quiver full of arrows. He shed the arrows on to
the ground at his feet and said, "The mighty contest is at an end. I
will now see whether Apoll'will vouchsafe it t'me t'hit another mark
which n'man has yet hit."
On this he aimed a deadly arrow at Antinous, wh'was about t'take up a
two-handled gold cup t'drink his wine and already had it in his hands.
He had n'thought of death—wh'amongst all the revellers would think
that one man, however brave, would stand alone among s'many and kill
him? The arrow struck Antinous in the throat, and the point went clean
through his neck, s'that he fell over and the cup dropped from his
hand, while a thick stream of blood gushed from his nostrils. He kicked
the table from him and upset the things on it, s'that the bread and
roasted meats were all soiled as they fell over on t'the ground.166
The suitors were in an uproar when they saw that a man had been hit;
they sprang in dismay one and all of them from their seats and looked
everywhere towards the walls, but there was neither shield nor spear,
and they rebuked Ulysses very angrily. "Stranger," said they, "you
shall pay for shooting people in this way: you shall see n'other
contest; you are a doomed man; he whom you have slain was the foremost
youth in Ithaca, and the vultures shall devour you for having killed
him."
Thus they spoke, for they thought that he had killed Antinous by
mistake, and did not perceive that death was hanging over the head of
every one of them. But Ulysses glared at them and said:
"Dogs, did you think that I should not come back from Troy? You have
wasted my substance,167 have forced my women servants t'lie with you,
and have wooed my wife while I was still living. You have feared
neither God nor man, and now you shall die."

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Avenges himself on the suitors
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Ulysses is furious and vengeful, confronting the suitors about their wrongdoings.

characters.name: Antinous
characters.role: Victim of Ulysses' revenge
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Antinous was caught off guard by Ulysses' attack, showing shock as he was struck by the arrow.

characters.name: The Suitors
characters.role: React to Ulysses' actions
characters.quote: Stranger, said they, you shall pay for shooting people in this way: you shall see n'other contest; you are a doomed man; he whom you have slain was the foremost youth in Ithaca, and the vultures shall devour you for having killed him.

scenes.title: The Suitors' Panic
scenes.summary: The suitors panic and try to defend themselves.
scenes.text:
They turned pale with fear as he spoke, and every man looked round
about t'see whither he might fly for safety, but Eurymachus alone
spoke.
"If you are Ulysses," said he, "then what you have said is just. We
have done much wrong on your lands and in your house. But Antinous who
was the head and front of the offending lies low already. It was all
his doing. It was not that he wanted t'marry Penelope; he did not so
much care about that; what he wanted was something quite different, and
Jove has not vouchsafed it t'him; he wanted t'kill your son and t'be
chief man in Ithaca. Now, therefore, that he has met the death which
was his due, spare the lives of your people. We will make everything
good among ourselves, and pay you in full for all that we have eaten
and drunk. Each one of us shall pay you a fine worth twenty oxen, and
we will keep on giving you gold and bronze till your heart is softened.
Until we have done this n'one can complain of your being enraged
against us."
Ulysses again glared at him and said, "Though you should give me all
that you have in the world both now and all that you ever shall have, I
will not stay my hand till I have paid all of you in full. You must
fight, or fly for your lives; and fly, not a man of you shall."
Their hearts sank as they heard him, but Eurymachus again spoke saying:
"My friends, this man will give us n'quarter. He will stand where he
is and shoot us down till he has killed every man among us. Let us then
show fight; draw your swords, and hold up the tables t'shield you from
his arrows. Let us have at him with a rush, t'drive him from the
pavement and doorway: we can then get through int'the town, and raise
such an alarm as shall soon stay his shooting."

characters.name: Eurymachus
characters.role: Attempts to negotiate for mercy
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Eurymachus feels fearful and desperate as he acknowledges their wrongs.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Determined to take revenge
characters.quote: Though you should give me all that you have in the world both now and all that you ever shall have, I will not stay my hand till I have paid all of you in full.

scenes.title: Telemachus Joins the Fight
scenes.summary: Telemachus arms himself and joins Ulysses.
scenes.text:
"Father, let me bring you a shield, tw'spears, and a brass helmet for
your temples. I will arm myself as well, and will bring other armour
for the swineherd and the stockman, for we had better be armed."
"Run and fetch them," answered Ulysses, "while my arrows hold out, or
when I am alone they may get me away from the door."
Telemachus did as his father said, and went off t'the store room where
the armour was kept. He chose four shields, eight spears, and four
brass helmets with horse-hair plumes. He brought them with all speed to
his father, and armed himself first, while the stockman and the
swineherd als'put on their armour, and took their places near Ulysses.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Father preparing for battle
characters.quote: Run and fetch them,

characters.name: Telemachus
characters.role: Son assisting his father
characters.quote: Father, let me bring you a shield, tw'spears, and a brass helmet for your temples.

characters.name: Stockman
characters.role: Supportive ally
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The stockman is prepared to support Ulysses and Telemachus in their defense.

characters.name: Swineherd
characters.role: Supportive ally
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The swineherd is prepared to support Ulysses and Telemachus in their defense.

scenes.title: Melanthius' Betrayal
scenes.summary: Melanthius brings arms to the suitors.
scenes.text:
On this the goatherd Melanthius went by back passages t'the store-room
of Ulysses' house. There he chose twelve shields, with as many helmets
and spears, and brought them back as fast as he could t'give them to
the suitors. Ulysses' heart began t'fail him when he saw the
suitors171 putting on their armour and brandishing their spears. He saw
the greatness of the danger, and said t'Telemachus, "Some one of the
women inside is helping the suitors against us, or it may be
Melanthius."
Telemachus answered, "The fault, father, is mine, and mine only; I left
the store room door open, and they have kept a sharper look out than I
have. Go, Eumaeus, put the door to, and see whether it is one of the
women wh'is doing this, or whether, as I suspect, it is Melanthius the
son of Dolius."
Thus did they converse. Meanwhile Melanthius was again going t'the
store room t'fetch more armour, but the swineherd saw him and said to
Ulysses wh'was beside him, "Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, it is that
scoundrel Melanthius, just as we suspected, wh'is going t'the store
room. Say, shall I kill him, if I can get the better of him, or shall I
bring him here that you may take your own revenge for all the many
wrongs that he has done in your house?"
Ulysses answered, "Telemachus and I will hold these suitors in check,
n'matter what they do; g'back both of you and bind Melanthius' hands
and feet behind him. Throw him int'the store room and make the door
fast behind you; then fasten a noose about his body, and string him
close up t'the rafters from a high bearing-post,172 that he may linger

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: Leader strategizing against suitors
characters.quote: Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, it is that scoundrel Melanthius, just as we suspected, wh'is going t'the store room.

characters.name: Telemachus
characters.role: Acknowledging his mistake and supporting Ulysses
characters.quote: The fault, father, is mine, and mine only; I left the store room door open, and they have kept a sharper look out than I have.

characters.name: Melanthius
characters.role: Antagonist aiding the suitors
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Melanthius is sneaking back to the store room to fetch more armor for the suitors, showing his betrayal.

characters.name: Eumaeus
characters.role: Loyal servant assisting Ulysses
characters.quote: Say, shall I kill him, if I can get the better of him, or shall I bring him here that you may take your own revenge for all the many wrongs that he has done in your house?

scenes.title: Minerva's Guidance
scenes.summary: Minerva encourages Ulysses and Telemachus in battle.
scenes.text:
Minerva came up t'them, having assumed the voice and form of Mentor.
Ulysses was glad when he saw her and said, "Mentor, lend me your help,
and forget not your old comrade, nor the many good turns he has done
you. Besides, you are my age-mate."
But all the time he felt sure it was Minerva, and the suitors from the
other side raised an uproar when they saw her. Agelaus was the first to
reproach her. "Mentor," he cried, "d'not let Ulysses beguile you into
siding with him and fighting the suitors. This is what we will do: when
we have killed these people, father and son, we will kill you too. You
shall pay for it with your head, and when we have killed you, we will
take all you have, in doors or out, and bring it int'hotch-pot with
Ulysses' property; we will not let your sons live in your house, nor
your daughters, nor shall your widow continue t'live in the city of
Ithaca."
This made Minerva still more furious, s'she scolded Ulysses very
angrily.173 "Ulysses," said she, "your strength and prowess are no
longer what they were when you fought for nine long years among the
Trojans about the noble lady Helen. You killed many a man in those
days, and it was through your stratagem that Priam's city was taken.
How comes it that you are s'lamentably less valiant now that you are
on your own ground, face t'face with the suitors in your own house?
Come on, my good fellow, stand by my side and see how Mentor, son of
Alcimus shall fight your foes and requite your kindnesses conferred
upon him."
But she would not give him full victory as yet, for she wished still
further t'prove his own prowess and that of his brave son, s'she flew
up t'one of the rafters in the roof of the cloister and sat upon it in
the form of a swallow.

characters.name: Minerva
characters.role: Disguised as Mentor, she encourages Ulysses to fight back against the suitors and tests his courage.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Minerva feels furious and determined as she confronts Ulysses about his diminished strength, reflecting her frustration over the current situation.

characters.name: Ulysses
characters.role: He seeks help from Mentor (Minerva) and feels a mix of hope and doubt about his current strength.
characters.quote: Mentor, lend me your help, and forget not your old comrade, nor the many good turns he has done you.

characters.name: Agelaus
characters.role: He threatens Minerva and Ulysses, showing the suitors' defiance and aggression.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Agelaus expresses aggression and a threatening demeanor, trying to manipulate Mentor against Ulysses, showcasing his desire to maintain control.

scenes.title: The Battle Intensifies
scenes.summary: The battle between Ulysses' men and the suitors escalates.
scenes.text:
Meanwhile Agelaus son of Damastor, Eurynomus, Amphimedon, Demoptolemus,
Pisander, and Polybus son of Polyctor bore the brunt of the fight upon
the suitors' side; of all those wh'were still fighting for their lives
they were by far the most valiant, for the others had already fallen
under the arrows of Ulysses. Agelaus shouted t'them and said, "My
friends, he will soon have t'leave off, for Mentor has gone away after
having done nothing for him but brag. They are standing at the doors
unsupported. D'not aim at him all at once, but six of you throw your
spears first, and see if you cannot cover yourselves with glory by
killing him. When he has fallen we need not be uneasy about the
others."
They threw their spears as he bade them, but Minerva made them all of
n'effect. One hit the door post; another went against the door; the
pointed shaft of another struck the wall; and as soon as they had
avoided all the spears of the suitors Ulysses said t'his own men, "My
friends, I should say we to'had better let drive int'the middle of
them, or they will crown all the harm they have done us by killing us
outright."
They therefore aimed straight in front of them and threw their spears.
Ulysses killed Demoptolemus, Telemachus Euryades, Eumaeus Elatus, while
the stockman killed Pisander. These all bit the dust, and as the others
drew back int'a corner Ulysses and his men rushed forward and regained
their spears by drawing them from the bodies of the dead.
The suitors now aimed a second time, but again Minerva made their
weapons for the most part without effect. One hit a bearing-post of the
cloister; another went against the door; while the pointed shaft of
another struck the wall. Still, Amphimedon just took a piece of the top
skin from off Telemachus's wrist, and Ctesippus managed t'graze
Eumaeus's shoulder above his shield; but the spear went on and fell to
the ground. Then Ulysses and his men let drive int'the crowd of
suitors. Ulysses hit Eurydamas, Telemachus Amphimedon, and Eumaeus
Polybus. After this the stockman hit Ctesippus in the breast, and
taunted him saying, "Foul-mouthed son of Polytherses, d'not be so
foolish as t'talk wickedly another time, but let heaven direct your
speech, for the gods are far stronger than men. I make you a present of
this advice t'repay you for the foot which you gave Ulysses when he
was begging about in his own house."
Thus spoke the stockman, and Ulysses struck the son of Damastor with a
spear in close fight, while Telemachus hit Leocritus son of Evenor in
the belly, and the dart went clean through him, s'that he fell forward
full on his face upon the ground. Then Minerva from her seat on the
rafter held up her deadly aegis, and the hearts of the suitors quailed.
They fled t'the other end of the court like a herd of cattle maddened
by the gadfly in early summer when the days are at their longest. As
eagle-beaked, crook-taloned vultures from the mountains swoop down on
the smaller birds that cower in flocks upon the ground, and kill them,
for they cannot either fight or fly, and lookers on enjoy the
sport—even s'did Ulysses and his men fall upon the suitors and smite
them on every side. They made a horrible groaning as their brains were
being battered in, and the ground seethed with their blood.

characters.name: Agelaus
characters.role: Leader of the suitors, encouraging them to fight
characters.quote: My friends, he will soon have t'leave off, for Mentor has gone away after having done nothing for him but brag. They are standing at the doors unsupported. D'not aim at him all at once, but six of you throw your spears first, and see if you cannot cover yourselves with glory by killing him. When he has fallen we need not be uneasy about the others.

characters.role: Heroic leader fighting against the suitors
characters.quote: My friends, I should say we to'had better let drive int'the middle of them, or they will crown all the harm they have done us by killing us outright.

characters.role: Ulysses' son, fighting alongside his father
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Telemachus shows bravery and determination as he fights alongside Ulysses, aiming to protect their home.

characters.name: Stockman
characters.role: Fighter against the suitors, taunting Ctesippus
characters.quote: Foul-mouthed son of Polytherses, d'not be so foolish as t'talk wickedly another time, but let heaven direct your speech, for the gods are far stronger than men. I make you a present of this advice t'repay you for the foot which you gave Ulysses when he was begging about in his own house.

characters.name: Ctesippus
characters.role: Suitor, attacked by the stockman
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Ctesippus feels defensive and fearful as he is attacked, realizing the consequences of his previous actions.
